HEADLINE: House Approves Highway Bill, Raising Prospect of Veto Showdown With Bush

BYLINE: By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
The House overwhelmingly approved a highway and transit measure on Friday that exceeds spending limits set by President Bush, raising the prospect of the first veto showdown between Mr. Bush and the Republican-led Congress over popular election-year legislation.
 House members voted 357 to 65 to approve the measure, which its authors said would provide $275 billion for highway construction, mass transit and safety programs over six years. It will now have to be reconciled with a Senate bill that spends $318 billion. 
 The White House has threatened to veto any bill that exceeds $256 billion, but both the House and Senate approved their bills by veto-proof margins.
 Even as the bill was being considered on the House floor, influential lawmakers were adding last-minute projects paid for out of about $1 billion that had not yet been allocated. 
 Speaker J. Dennis Hastert received $88 million for a bridge over the Fox River in his Northern Illinois district that aides said he had wanted for more than a decade. 
 Representative Don Young of Alaska, the chairman of the transportation committee, added tens of millions of dollars for new bridges in his state. 
 And Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, took home $70 million to help make the Golden Gate Bridge more resistant to earthquakes.
 ''These projects create jobs and will greatly enhance the economic and environmental vitality of the entire San Francisco Bay Area,'' Ms. Pelosi said.
 Supporters of the House bill say it is the bare minimum needed to keep pace with national transportation needs, and $100 billion below what they had wanted to spend. They included a provision to ''reopen'' the legislation in 2005 if spending levels are deemed inadequate.
 ''I will be back,'' said Mr. Young, who had initially pushed for $375 billion. ''I will continue this fight because I believe in it so strongly for this nation.''
 To many rank-and-file lawmakers, the highway measure is the most important legislation of the session because it allows them to funnel money directly back into their districts. The House bill includes about $11 billion for such special projects, with 3,200 outlined in the legislation and more expected to be added in negotiations with the Senate.
 Over two days of debate, House members defended their measure against a presidential veto threat, saying the legislation was essential to keeping the United States economy competitive and was a sure way to create high-paying jobs.
 ''Why some bean counters have determined that we can do this bill on the cheap when the infrastructure needs of this country are crying out for repair is beyond me,'' said Representative Steven C. LaTourette, Republican of Ohio.
 But the White House, seeking to demonstrate its commitment to cutting the mounting deficit, has indicated that it intends to stand firm against spending increases in the legislation, and that Mr. Bush could veto a measure that has bipartisan support.
 Hoping to avoid a confrontation between Mr. Bush and Congress, House leaders say they intend to keep the White House closely involved in the coming negotiations to avert a veto. 
 ''The speaker is going to work this out in conference with the White House so the president does not veto this job-creating bill,'' said John Feehery, a spokesman for Mr. Hastert.
 While the vote margins in both the House and Senate were well over the number needed to override a veto, some Republicans would probably switch their positions to support the president in a veto fight.
 The House vote was unusual for the Republican-controlled chamber because the bill was opposed by more Republicans -- 59 -- than Democrats -- 6. Voting in favor were 194 Democrats, 162 Republicans and one independent.
 Republican opponents included those who said the bill was too expensive and overloaded with special projects, and lawmakers from Florida, Georgia and elsewhere who believed the measure penalized their states. They voted against it after an effort to change the financing allocation was defeated by those from states that would have seen their money drop. A Democratic-led effort to raise the spending to equal the Senate was also rejected.
 Among those opposing the measure was the No. 3 Republican in the House, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the party whip. He said that if the measure was not improved, he would vote to sustain a veto. ''The final legislation needs to be a six-year bill, not a bill that has to be reopened in two years,'' he said.
 Negotiations between the House and Senate are expected to begin after the Easter recess. The federal highway program is now operating under a short-term extension that expires on April 30. Unless final legislation is approved by then or the program extended again, highway projects around the country could be shut down and transportation workers laid off.

HEADLINE: Developer Buys Faded Market In the Bronx

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
For three decades, the Bronx Terminal Market has been mired in political scandal and decay as New York City battled in court interminably with the family that had leased the property and ran the fruit and vegetable market into the ground.
 Now, under a three-way deal signed yesterday, the Buntzman family finally relinquished its hold on the dilapidated 31-acre market near Yankee Stadium. Related Companies, the developer that is completing Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, bought out the Buntzmans' lease with the city. The company plans to build a large multilevel retail complex and garage on the property, with an esplanade and a park along the Harlem River. The project, however, will take several years to wend its way through the city's approval process. 
 ''Hallelujah!'' exclaimed the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrion Jr. ''It's been an open sore for us. It made for a pretty darn ugly gateway to the Bronx.''
 David Buntzman, the 96-year-old family patriarch, could not be reached at his home in Sarasota, Fla., and his lawyer did not return calls requesting comment.
 Related declined to say how much it paid for the Buntzman lease, but according to one person involved in the negotiations, the developer agreed to pay the Buntzmans more than $40 million. 
 The deal brings to an end years of litigation between the city, which owns the property, and the Buntzmans, who obtained a 99-year lease for the market in 1972, shortly after Mr. Buntzman delivered $30,000 in cash to Mayor John V. Lindsay's flagging presidential campaign in Wisconsin. 
 State investigators subpoenaed a number of Lindsay administration officials who went on to become major public figures, including Jeffrey Katzenberg, who became chairman of Walt Disney Studios and a co-founder of DreamWorks SKG, and Richard Aurelio, who later was president of Time Warner's City Cable Group and founder of New York 1 News. But a special prosecutor found no evidence to indict anyone.
 A series of politically connected lawyers and lobbyists kept the city at bay for decades as the market fell into disrepair. The Buntzmans also sued the city, claiming that it had failed to live up to its obligations under the lease.
 Andrew M. Alper, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said in a statement issued yesterday that Related's takeover of the lease was a positive sign for the Bronx. ''Today's agreement is a major step forward that will enable us to move ahead with the Bronx Terminal Market project,'' Mr. Alper said, ''which will create thousands of jobs for the Bronx and generate enormous economic activity and tax revenue for the city.''
 For now, Jeffrey Blau, president of Related, said his company would continue to run the market, where fewer than 30 fruit and vegetable wholesalers are operating in the buildings along the cobblestone streets. Built in the 1920's, it was once one of the largest Hispanic food wholesale operations in the country, with more than 100 tenants and more than 1,000 employees.
 The paint is faded and blistering on many of the crumbling buildings, with broken windows on the second floors. In the next few months, Related plans to demolish the hulking brick refrigerated warehouse that was once the market's central structure. Eventually, the tenants will be relocated elsewhere in the Bronx, and Related will redevelop the site.
 ''In 32 years, what did the Buntzmans do?'' asked one wholesaler, Omar Duarte, with a shrug of his shoulders. ''Nothing, except raised the rent. If you don't invest in something for 32 years, of course it gets run down.''
 Mr. Duarte's father, Ricardo, has run Cuba Tropical in the best-kept building at the market for the past quarter-century. But they have mixed feelings about the future. ''It could be a good thing,'' the younger Mr. Duarte said. ''But I wouldn't want to move. We have a great location. It's a one-stop shop for a lot of our customers, bodegas, supermarkets and restaurants.''
 Three years after Mr. Buntzman obtained the lease for the market, he became the subject of state and city investigations into whether he used political influence to get a sweetheart deal from the city. Wholesalers at the market who were in a dispute with the family told state investigators that Mr. Buntzman had laughed at them when they threatened to take their complaints to the city. They said he boasted of flying out to Wisconsin with a bag of cash for Mr. Lindsay's campaign.
 Investigators later found that Mr. Buntzman had contributed $30,000 shortly before he got the lease. The lease was renegotiated in 1973, relieving him of millions of dollars in obligations to rehabilitate the market. But the investigation did not result in any indictments. 
 The city cited the family for the illegal dumping of asbestos in 1988, and in 1991, it filed a $1.8 million lawsuit against the Buntzmans, saying the market was plagued by poor management, filthy conditions and illegal dumping. In 1993, Mayor David N. Dinkins described the market as ''an atrocious eyesore'' and sought to condemn the Buntzman lease, and a few years later the borough president, Fernando Ferrer, called for the creation of a sports-oriented retail and entertainment center on the site, Yankee Village. The Buntzmans countersued, claiming that the city had failed to invest in the market and walled off a vital elevated roadway that connected the market to the Major Deegan Expressway.
 Also at issue were the Buntzmans' rent payments to the city. In recent years, they had paid about $120,000 a year in rent, but the city claimed that the family was millions of dollars in arrears, though the Buntzmans denied that allegation. Related will pay the city about $250,000 a year in rent, according to city officials. With a trial date looming, a concerted effort began about a year ago to settle the dispute. Richard Ravitch, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was brought in by both sides to mediate. Finally, a deal was struck with Related.
 ''This is a very happy ending to a tragic 30-year history of disinvestment and the Buntzmans' failure to fulfill the public interest incumbent upon a long-term lessee of city property,'' said Carl Weisbrod, a former president of the city's Economic Development Corporation who tried to break the lease.


CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 3 about the transfer of control of the Bronx Terminal Market misstated an aspect of the 1970's investigation into the granting of a 99-year lease to David Buntzman after he made a $30,000 contribution to the presidential campaign of Mayor John V. Lindsay. Richard Aurelio, Mr. Lindsay's campaign manager, says he was never subpoenaed in the case, and prosecutors also say they have no recollection or record of any such subpoena, although they investigated Mr. Aurelio's role at the time.

HEADLINE: Conservative Takes On Moderate G.O.P. Senator in Pennsylvania

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa., March 29 

 BODY:
Representative Patrick J. Toomey, Republican candidate for Senate in Pennsylvania, has been ripping his opponent for being a ''Ted Kennedy'' liberal, too fond of taxes and spending, too close to activist judges and trial lawyers, too supportive of abortion rights and the United Nations.
 Never mind that his opponent, Senator Arlen Specter, is a four-term Republican who has been endorsed by the nation's conservative-in-chief, President Bush. Party cleansing, not party unity, is Mr. Toomey's goal.
 ''The problem we've got is a handful of Republican senators who never really bought into the idea of the Republican Party in the first place,'' Mr. Toomey told a group of gray-suited businessmen in this conservative city. ''I represent the Republican wing of the Republican Party.'' 
 Generously financed by an antitax group, the Club for Growth, Mr. Toomey is giving Mr. Specter his toughest primary since he won election 24 years ago. Mr. Toomey has closed to within 13 points or less, recent polls show, with less than a month left before primary day on April 27.
 But while a Specter defeat would be a momentous event in Pennsylvania politics, the race is capturing national attention for another reason. Mr. Specter, 74, is the elder statesman of a dwindling band of centrist Republicans in Congress. In taking him on, Mr. Toomey, 42, and his conservative backers are hoping to send a message to all Republican moderates: turn right or face costly challenges. 
 ''If we beat Specter, we won't have any trouble with wayward Republicans anymore,'' said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, which has spent nearly $1 million on advertisements criticizing Mr. Specter. The club's members have contributed about $800,000 to Mr. Toomey's campaign.
 ''It serves notice to Chafee, Snowe, Voinovich and others who have been problem children that they will be next,'' Mr. Moore said, referring to three moderate Republican senators: Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, Olympia J. Snowe of Maine and George V. Voinovich of Ohio. 
 Under this pressure, Mr. Specter has spent much of the campaign underscoring his conservative credentials. He routinely meets with gun groups, heralding his support for gun rights, lower taxes and smaller government. And he starts every speech with anecdotes about Mr. Bush while distributing fliers featuring Vice President Cheney. 
 But Mr. Specter is also unabashed in his disdain for the Club for Growth, which he calls a gang of ''Wall Street tycoons.'' Mr. Toomey, he says, is ''not far right, he's far out.'' 
 ''Virtually everybody except the Club for Growth and my primary opponent agree that a big tent is necessary to be the prevailing national party,'' Mr. Specter said in an interview. 
 Although the Club for Growth is by far Mr. Toomey's biggest backer, an array of prominent conservatives have endorsed his campaign, including the National Right To Life Committee and the National Taxpayers Union Campaign Fund. Grover G. Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform and James C. Dobson, chairman of Focus on the Family, have also given endorsements. 
 ''Specter has been a one-man road block to the confirmation of conservative, pro-family judges,'' Dr. Dobson wrote to supporters. He also accused Mr. Specter of helping to block a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage.
 Mr. Specter says that while he believes marriage is between a man and a woman, states should pass their own laws defining the institution. Mr. Toomey supports the federal amendment.
 But conservatives have not been monolithic in their support of Mr. Toomey, who represents the 15th Congressional District in eastern Pennsylvania. Most prominently, the National Rifle Association, one of the largest and most effective political operations on the right, has endorsed Mr. Specter. Though Mr. Toomey has perhaps a stronger record on gun rights, the association has a policy of protecting incumbents who support their major positions.
 Rick Santorum, Pennsylvania's junior senator and a darling of the conservative movement, has also appeared in Specter advertisements. Mr. Moore, of the Club for Growth, said conservatives who back Mr. Specter were missing a crucial opportunity. ''For 25 years, they have complained about Specter,'' he said. ''Now we've got this guy cornered and we can actually replace him, and yet there are some conservatives that are sitting on the sidelines.''
 But some leading conservatives argue that the Club for Growth blundered by making the race a high-profile test of the conservative movement because Mr. Specter might be too hard to defeat. Despite his moderate positions, these conservatives say, he is not ''the worst Republican senator,'' as the National Review said on its cover last year. 
 ''Specter is hard to peg,'' said one leading conservative, who did not want to be identified as breaking with other conservatives. ''He can be with you sometimes.''
 Mr. Toomey comes from a working-class family, graduated from Harvard on scholarships, worked in international finance and opened a restaurant before winning an open Congressional seat in 1998. 
 In Congress, he advocated supply-side economics, supporting cuts to the estate and corporate gains taxes, a flat income tax and individual investment accounts for Social Security.
 On the stump, Mr. Toomey pokes fun at projects Mr. Specter has voted for as part of appropriations bills, including a rainforest in Iowa. 
 ''He is rated one of the Senate's most wasteful spenders,'' says a commercial from Club for Growth. ''John Kerry? No. Arlen Specter.''
 Mr. Toomey also warns that if Mr. Specter is re-elected, and the Republicans retain control of the Senate, Mr. Specter will probably become chairman of the Judiciary Committee, where he could block conservative bills and judicial nominees. 
 ''You could argue his liberalism didn't matter when Bill Clinton was president because we weren't going to get conservative legislation signed into law,'' Mr. Toomey said. ''We do have the opportunity now.''
 Mr. Specter grew up in Russell, Kan., went to college in Philadelphia and became the city's district attorney before getting elected to the Senate in 1980. His arguments for re-election are bluntly pragmatic. He contends Mr. Toomey is too rigidly ideological to win the general election, having voted contrary to the state's Republican Congressional delegation 76 times in five years. Mr. Specter also promotes his seniority, his constituent services and the money he delivers to communities. 
 That kind of clout seems to be what many local Republicans want. ''Money goes with seniority,'' said Dave Cyphert, chairman of the Clarion County Board of Commissioners in conservative northwestern Pennsylvania. 
 Incumbency has also helped Mr. Specter vastly out raise Mr. Toomey, collecting $11.5 million in contributions to Mr. Toomey's $2.5 million. With less than a month to go, Mr. Specter has more than $9 million on hand compared with $2 million for Mr. Toomey, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. 
 Both candidates contend they can help Mr. Bush carry Pennsylvania, which he narrowly lost in 2000. Mr. Toomey asserts he will energize conservatives; Mr. Specter argues he can help the president among swing voters and centrist Democrats. 
 But the biggest factors in determining the primary, analysts say, may be turnout and anti-incumbent sentiment. A low turnout dominated by conservatives could favor Mr. Toomey, the analysts said. Polls also indicate that dissatisfaction with Mr. Specter runs high among Republicans. But that is balanced by Mr. Toomey's lack of name recognition.
 Mr. Specter's weakness is also his strength, said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Keystone Poll at Franklin & Marshall College. ''He's practical. He gets things done. The pragmatic conservatives may say: 'he delivers, even if we don't agree with him.' ''

HEADLINE: Seeing the Car Show Through Insiders' Eyes

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
GIVEN that the car business is one of the world's most cutthroat industries, it is no surprise that the people who work for auto companies pay close attention to the competition. What might be surprising is how generous they can be in praise for their rivals.
 While not exactly a mutual-admiration society, the men and women who design, engineer and sell vehicles -- and come together at a few leading industry shows, like the New York International Auto Show that opens on Friday -- are often free with compliments for the competition.
 As in past years, The New York Times asked prominent people in the industry to evaluate the cars and trucks introduced earlier this year at the Detroit auto show (most of which will be displayed in New York), and to pick their favorites. Once again, there was only one ground rule: products from their own companies were off limits. 
 Here are the cars and trucks that the insiders liked best, and why:

Anne Asensio, General Motors
Executive director for advanced design.

FORD MUSTANG: ''I kind of react very well with the 60's Mustang because it was the Mustang I saw in France as a kid. It was for me very much an icon.''

LINCOLN AVIATOR CONCEPT: ''What was interesting was that Lincoln was working very hard at getting the brand identity. I really like that concept. It is very well proportioned. It was easy to love.''

MERCEDES-BENZ VISION GST: ''It's impressive the way they are utilizing the interior space. I really like this glass roof and very light leather that gives you an incredible feeling of space and feeling good inside.''

TOYOTA FTX CONCEPT: ''The blue concept truck with the very big front grille was definitely a very bold statement. Usually Toyota is really refined, finessed, but a little bit understated. It was interesting to see Toyota really getting into the design with this truck. By design I mean, 'I'm going to be bold, as I would be in America.' This is what is surprising with this truck.''

Donald V. Esmond, Toyota
General manager of the Toyota Division of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A.

FORD FIVE HUNDRED: ''It's going to be pretty good competition. From the outside, about Taurus size, but certainly a lot bigger on the inside, with a pretty huge trunk and V-6. It feels like you sit a little higher in it, a little more of the S.U.V. king-of-the-road feel. The all-wheel-drive option is a big plus.''

CHEVROLET COBALT: ''I think they've done a good job with the overall package and an excellent job on the interior, really taken it a little more upscale.''

HONDA S.U.T. CONCEPT: ''I think from their perspective they are listening to the customer, and the customer wants more utility, wants to haul passengers and have some utility. The product they've rolled out certainly will do that.''

Ralph Gilles, DaimlerChrysler
Design director for the Chrysler Group.

PONTIAC SOLSTICE: ''I have to give G.M. a lot of credit for making that vehicle for that price [about $20,000]. It has a pretty dramatic proportion for its size.''

FORD MUSTANG: ''It is interesting to see a car that is so uniquely American. The surface is very taut. We use a word in design: it's tight, taut. There are a lot of lines that go from stem to stern that stabilize the design and organize it nicely.''

FORD BRONCO CONCEPT: ''It was honest, a pure statement. Some of the S.U.V.'s they have been doing have tried to be carlike in their execution. This is very trucklike, very robust looking, almost like a giant toy.''

Len Hunt, Volkswagen
Vice president for sales and marketing, Volkswagen of America.

PONTIAC SOLSTICE: ''I think it even went beyond where the concept was. We all liked it when we saw it as a concept. Then we saw the real one and thought that's even better. We can now really give to the customer the designer's dream.''

CHRYSLER ME FOUR-TWELVE: ''In this world of fuel economy concerns, there was the ME Four-Twelve supercar. There is still a voracious appetite for huge horsepower.''

INFINITI QX56: ''They are coming in and saying, 'We're going into every section of the market.' It's saying, 'I'm going to come into your luxury market with the G35, which I did and did it very successfully. I'm coming into your coupe-kind-of-crossover market with my FX series, and now I'm coming in with the big trucks.''

NISSAN FRONTIER: ''They are a force to be reckoned with, both in their Infiniti and Nissan brands, and the Nissan Frontier would be a good example. It means there's nothing sacred anymore. They are going to have full coverage of the market and they are going to take on anybody.''

Robert A. Lutz, G.M.
Chairman, G.M. North America.

FORD FIVE HUNDRED: ''It is very space- and package-efficient and seems to have a very nice interior from a craftsmanship standpoint. But to me the interesting thing is the broad reuse of that front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive architecture, the fact that it shares a common architecture with the Ford Freestyle and allegedly with some Volvo models. If you do it cleverly, you can get quite an array of vehicles that all look and behave very differently.''

FORD MUSTANG: ''It is the first Mustang in ages that totally recaptures what the original five years of Mustangs were all about. I think in that sense Ford has a substantial hit.''

CHRYSLER 300 AND DODGE MAGNUM: ''They are very bold departures from conventional automotive design. They are very static-looking; they have a very large, blunt nose; and in many ways are reminiscent of American cars of the 50's. I think it's a very risky design direction. I'm not sure I would have dared do that. It could be that it's going to be hugely successful -- in which case I will say, 'I wish I'd thought of that.'''

J Mays, Ford
Group vice president for design.

PONTIAC SOLSTICE: ''I think they've done a very nice job of bringing it into production, and if they can bring it to the market for under $20,000 it's a very high-quality little two-seat roadster. It's a nice proportion; the shape has lightened and matured from concept to production.''

TOYOTA FTX: ''I think the overall shape of that vehicle was a bit of a head fake; I don't believe that's what the design will look like once it comes to production, but Toyota was implying that they are entering into the full-size-truck arena. Obviously that has huge ramifications.''

AUDI A8 L 6.0 QUATTRO: ''The front end was quite a fist on the table saying, 'This is the direction we are headed.' The front was very authoritative and had a lot of presence. They are no longer either technically or from a design standpoint standing in the shadow of Mercedes.''

MERCEDES-BENZ VISION GST: ''Maybe it was most significant for me because of the level of color and material sophistication found on the interior. It was an absolutely stunning combination of materials, textures and colors.''

Joel Piaskowski, Hyundai
Chief designer, Hyundai Kia Design and Technical Center.

PONTIAC G6: ''It is the first real Pontiac under Bob Lutz. It still has a lot of Pontiac flair and character but done with a very international design sense. It's a very clean, pure design statement. It's the first vehicle that will change the face of Pontiac for years to come.''

PONTIAC SOLSTICE: ''It is a pretty darned good interpretation of the show car. As a designer you can see some things that were compromised to allow for federalization and packaging. Some of the proportions changed a little bit; the car got a little bit larger. But to Joe Public, it's a show car at a price point that's going to be very affordable.''

FORD MUSTANG: ''The Mustang is significant because it is a big departure from its predecessor. The new one is really going back to its heritage.''

VOLVO S40: ''It has this tough, squat, bulldog appearance, kind of hunkered down. It has a real good stance to it. The lines have a lot of motion.''

Tom Semple, Nissan

HEADLINE: On the Soup Line, Lives Gone Awry

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS. 
E-mail: amh@nytimes.com

 BODY:
SHE had a strong sense of the punch line, the catchy refrain in every story. ''I love my mother, but '' was one of her punch lines. ''I love my mother, but '' she read from a short memoir she had written in blue ink on a piece of lined notebook paper. ''But,'' the woman continued, hers is the kind of mother who, on Mother's Day, ''always flips the card over to check the bar code to see how much I paid for her greeting.''
 Another punch line was ''pearls in a soup kitchen.'' She knew it must look funny, wearing a pinstripe suit, pink-shell top and pearls, then lining up to eat the free spaghetti and meatballs in the soup kitchen at Church of the Holy Apostles in Chelsea. ''Pearls in a soup kitchen,'' she said, smiling at the irony. 
 Tory Connolly Walker, the woman of many punch lines, was a little better dressed than most -- but not all -- of the people who ate lunch last week at the soup kitchen, on 28th Street and Ninth Avenue. It's a cliche, of course, having a Harvard degree one day and being down and out the next, or having a job in making pizza one day and sleeping at the Atlantic Avenue men's shelter in Brooklyn the next.
 But in these times of conflicting employment statistics, the cliches live at the Holy Apostles soup kitchen, where you can walk in Monday through Friday and find a real-life character out of a Frank Capra movie. There's Chris, who has a Harvard degree in mathematics and lives in a rooming house a few blocks away, compulsively repeating information about the etymology of names (''Did you know that Pedro means Peter and Pablo means Paul?''). He says his wife deserted him 30 years ago, when he had his first mental breakdown, and he raised his twin sons with the help of his sister; those sons are now physics professors at Cornell. 
 Another regular is Andrew, homeless since he was kicked out of a job he won't specify by an employer who, he says, has ''blackballed'' him for four years. With earnings from panhandling, he buys several newspapers a day, scans them for news about homeless people and hones his lunch-table conversation. ''We talk a lot about the economy, the situation with the president, the way Republicans are presenting themselves as champions of America,'' he said, ''even though this is an artificial recovery, and future generations will be paying for it through the ballooning national debt.'' 
 Chris and Andrew carry photo ID cards distributed by the soup kitchen, the way people carry identification from an employer. 
 But there are plenty of others at the soup kitchen, perhaps the majority, who are poor, uneducated and never had much of a chance. They are people like David, who says he was earning $400 a week off the books making pizza in Newark before being laid off a month ago because businesswas slow. 
 ''The shelter system in Newark is horrible,'' he said the other day, pouring himself a cup of coffee out of a giant urn. ''It's what I heard New York used to be in the 80's, where you gotta sleep with your shoes on. The smaller towns like Bergen County, they put you up in a motel on Route 46, with a color TV and air conditioning, and they give you food stamps. But then you run into transportation problems.'' That's why he came to New York.
 It seems unlikely that anyone not truly hungry would seek out the soup kitchen's food. On Thursday it was turkey ham, frozen vegetables, reconstituted mashed potatoes, stewed figs and bread, all heavy on the salt and hardly Balducci-fresh. Still, this soup kitchen gets good word of mouth because the portions are generous and, unlike many others, allows second helpings.
 To some, the scene at the soup kitchen is ineffably sad, a Frank Capra movie in reverse, with no redemptive payoff at the end. To others it is inspiring. Clyde Kuemmerle, the gray-bearded soup kitchen coordinator, a former theatrical producer and agent who worked out of the Sardi's building before he went broke, says he sees the face of Jesus, though sometimes with difficulty, in every person who comes through the feeding line. 
 He can see Jesus, for instance, in Tory Connolly Walker, who was a radio reporter for WOSU-AM, the NPR affiliate in Columbus, Ohio, 22 years ago, before succumbing to manic depression and crack. Ms. Walker, 48, says she is off drugs, and is the star student in a writers' workshop held after lunch at the soup kitchen. She has also made a small step toward rejoining the world of journalism. She distributes the free daily newspaper AM New York in the subways for $9 an hour, three hours a day. It's a wonderful life.

HEADLINE: Fast Response May Reduce Any Economic Hit to State

BYLINE: By GEORGINA GUSTIN

 BODY:
THE 100-or-so-mile stretch of Interstate 95 from Greenwich to the Rhode Island border is an artery: clog it up and the body shudders.
 The closure of Connecticut's most traveled and chronically troubled route temporarily changed the state's entire transportation infrastructure. Trucks were re-routed to Interstate 84 or onto ferries crossing Long Island Sound; cars did the same or made their ways, very, very slowly, onto the Merritt Parkway. Trains, often ignored modes of transport, particularly east of New Haven, saw spikes in ridership.
 The transportation network shifted and absorbed to accommodate the new patterns, and so did the people and businesses who depend on it. But while their response certainly lessened the impact of the accident, it was the quick repair of the highway that may have saved the state a big economic hit. Some of the state's business analysts said the economic impact was likely to be minimal. 
 ''If it had lasted longer, you might've seen a more dramatic impact,'' said John Markowicz, a member of the state's Transportation Strategy Board, a group charged with finding transportation options for the state. ''We expected this to last a month and basically it lasted about a week.''
 Still, while it lasted, businesses were affected. Some saw business go up, some had it decline so badly that they gave workers an unexpected vacation and some saw their expenses rise as truckers, stuck for hours in traffic and sent miles out of their way on detours, passed along the extra money they were spending to deliver goods. 
 ''It's been real slow, '' said Coleen Quackenbush, a cashier at the Secondi Brothers travel plaza off Exit 40, where, last Sunday, only a handful of tractor-trailers idled in the parking lot, and the restaurant was closed because of slow business. ''They've been cutting back our hours because there's been no business. I'm sure other places are doing the same thing.''
 Secondi Brothers and two other truck stops along a stretch of I-95 between Milford and New Haven were ghost towns for a while. But when the northbound lanes of the highway opened earlier than expected last Sunday around 5 p.m., the lifeblood flowed back in.
 ''Business has picked up since they opened up the northbound lanes,'' Mike Lake, a shift supervisor, said last week before the southbound lanes opened also. He said that Secondi management allowed a few employees to go on vacation because they expected the road to remain closed for weeks. ''They were looking at a week.''
 For Secondi and other businesses along I-95, the closure of the interstate delivered a mercifully short blow.
 ''We did see a pretty big impact at that particular store,'' said Jim Taylor, a spokesman for the Cracker Barrel chain, referring to the restaurant just up the road from Secondi. ''But the business is coming back. The local folks were coming, but the travelers couldn't get there.''
 Truckers, not surprisingly, were especially hard hit by the closures, prompting some truckers to ask the state for financial relief.
 ''It's been a challenge, but we're delivering freight everywhere we need to deliver it,'' said Mike Riley of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut. ''It's just going slower and it's going to cost more. If we have a driver who's supposed to be back in two hours and it takes eight, it's going to cost more in salary and gas.'' 
 Mr. Riley said truckers were levying surcharges onto the companies they delivered to, and he expected those costs could ultimately get passed on to consumers.
 ''The trucking industry can't absorb this cost,'' he said, explaining: ''If a guy brings oranges from Florida and he gets caught in the mess, he's on the road for four or five hours longer than expected. That's fuel and money he can't afford, so he's going to charge a surcharge.''
 Some companies, though, aren't in the time-sensitive business of produce.
 ''Obviously, if our customers can't get to us that's not a good thing for business,'' said Steve Mullen, a spokesman for the electronics chain, Circuit City, who said he wasn't aware of any delivery problems to the company's stores in the Northeast. ''Unfortunately, if we have to deliver a day later, while unfortunate, it's not like someone's going to lose the product.''
 For other businesses, the closure of I-95 rerouted traffic in their favor, providing a fleeting economic boom-let. At Exit 25 northbound in Bridgeport, traffic was rerouted for nearly three full days, from Thursday night to Sunday, on a route that led through the city's downtown, along State Street. At the McDonald's restaurant along the detour route, the marquis announced, ''Now Open 24 Hours,'' and at a Kennedy Fried Chicken on State Street, trucks and cars filled the parking lot.
 ''It was more than before,'' said the owner, Abdul Aminy. ''A lot more traffic, a lot more trucks.'' But, said Mr. Aminy, he wasn't sorry to see the northbound lanes open again, because his regular customers were actually thwarted from their usual visits by the new traffic. ''We like it normal, it's much better than busy,'' he said. ''Then people can go back to their lives.''
 For Metro-North and at least one of the state's ferry operators, the hobbling of I-95 just reiterated the interstate's persistent blockages while boosting passenger loads in the process.
 On Metro-North, ridership from New Haven to Grand Central jumped over all by 4,000 customers in the days following the I-95 closure. From New Haven to Stamford or Greenwich -- on intrastate travel -- ridership went up by 75 to 90 percent, or between 2,500 and 3,000 riders.
 ''Certainly, this boost, this eye-popping increase, is a testament to the fact that the system is in place,'' said Dan Brucker, a Metro-North spokesman, ''and we believe these customers will stick to Metro-North after the I-95 bridge reopens because we have given them 100 percent, on-time performance, which is far better than what they can do in their automobile -- without melting bridges.''
 After the closure, federal officials asked ferry companies to bump up their slow-season schedules to usher cars and trucks across Long Island Sound, but Cross Sound Ferry in New London had anticipated the stress on I-95 and had ramped up their schedule already.
 ''The demand was there because of the closure,'' said Stan Mickus, director of marketing for Cross Sound Ferry, which ran hourly, and even half-hourly, ferries between New London and Orient Point, N.Y., to accommodate the increased flow, but has returned to its normal pre-summer schedule now that I-95 is back open. The Bridgeport-Port Jefferson ferry also increased service, which will continue until after Easter weekend.
 Advocates of alternatives to highway travel, including the companies that run rail and sea operations, said the accident underscores the need to look at more environmentally and user-friendly mass-transit options.
 ''What's taking place on I-95 and on 495, is a major reason the demand for our services has gone up,'' Mr. Mickus said. ''People would rather be on a boat than sitting in traffic.''
 In southeastern Connecticut, the Foxwoods Resort Casino and Mohegan Sun Casino, officials said, were unhurt by the accident.
 ''In fact, we not only didn't have any cancellations of our bus passengers, but we had one of our strongest days in terms of that market segment,'' said Mitchell Etess, executive vice president of marketing for Mohegan Sun, referring to last weekend. ''We were somewhat concerned, and perhaps a bit surprised it didn't affect us. The travel up was not as severely impacted as we thought, and apparently the bus operators have alternate routes they use in the summer, and they basically resorted to those routes.''
 Officials at the Mystic Coast and Country Travel and Industry Association, the tourism bureau for the Mystic area, said they were also surprised by the minimal effect of the I-95 shut down. At Mystic Seaport, for example, attendance last weekend was actually up over the same weekend last year.
 ''I think we may have dodged a bullet on this one,'' said Chris Jennings, president of Mystic Coast and Country. ''Everyone was braced for bad news.''
 Some of the state's business analysts said, because the closure was relatively brief, the economic impacts were likely to be minimal, though it was too soon to quantify.
 ''It's impossible to accurately estimate the impact on the business community,'' said Jim Watson of the State Department of Economic and Community Development. ''There are too many variables, especially with the alternative routes available.''
 The quick work of construction crews will have minimized the economic hit.
 Mr. Markowicz of the Transportation Strategy Board said the state, region, and even nationwide glitches caused by the blockage of just one road should be a wake-up call for transportation strategists and lawmakers.
 ''If I had to make a recommendation it would be for the transportation department to do an assessment of what the impact was,'' Mr. Markowicz said. ''If you take a look at what happened this past week, you have an indicator of what could happen in 10 years on 95. It'll be a parking lot. Maybe it's time to look at alternatives.''

LENGTH: 554 words

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried

 BODY:

Officer's Killer Fails To Regain Windfall
 Sixteen years after drug gangsters executed a rookie police officer in New York City -- and long after they were imprisoned and exhausted their appeals -- legal ripples still emerge from the notorious killing.
 In February 1988, the officer, Edward Byrne, 22, above, was shot in the head five times as he sat alone in a patrol car guarding the home of a drug case witness in South Jamaica, Queens. 
 Four men were convicted in 1989 of murdering Officer Byrne and sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. 
 In 1999, one of them, David McClary, was awarded $660,000 by a federal court jury after he sued the state for having kept him in solitary confinement for four years. The jury found that his civil rights had been violated and that he had suffered mental distress during his long isolation; it rejected the argument that he had to be segregated because his notoriety had made him a possible target for other prisoners. A judge reduced the amount to $237,500.
 Political leaders were among the angry critics of the award, and in 2001 they changed a state law to enable Officer Byrne's family to claim the money. 
 Previously, the so-called Son of Sam law -- named for the 1970's serial killer David Berkowitz -- permitted victims or their survivors to sue those convicted in their cases for proceeds derived from the crimes, like royalties from a book. Now they can sue for virtually any money the prisoners receive. The Byrne family sued, and got the $237,500.
 But that was not the end, Mr. McClary's lawyer said recently. She said Mr. McClary sued in federal court in 2002 to have the revision of the state law declared unconstitutional. The state had ''changed the rules suddenly,'' said the lawyer, Anna Marie Richmond, ''depriving him of due process of law'' and other rights.
 But last month the suit was dismissed, she said, with the court finding that it lacked jurisdiction to consider the claim.
 Mr. McClary, 38, is now in the general inmate population in the Shawangunk Correctional Facility in Wallkill.
 Where Ms. Richmond said the money had been a valid award for his mistreatment in prison, the Byrne family's lawyer, John P. McEntee, said the family was ''relieved that he was not able to profit from killing their son.''

Instead of a Museum, Hungry Mollusks
 The museum is not coming. The wood-eating water creatures are feasting.
 That, in a seashell, is the story of two city-owned piers on the East River in Lower Manhattan.
 In 2000, the Guggenheim Museum said it would build an outpost on a site that included the old piers. But in 2002 the museum canceled the widely publicized Frank Gehry plan, above, for financial reasons.
 The piers, 13 and 14, now lie vacant. The city, also in 2002, ousted a tennis club from them, saying they had become unsafe.
 The city's Economic Development Corporation said recently that the piers' future now depended on an overall plan being drawn up for the East River waterfront. 
 But the planners may not be the only ones with a say in whether Piers 13 and 14 survive. The damage making them unsafe has been caused by marine borers, tiny mollusks and crustaceans that eat away at wood pilings. The erosion ''happens quickly once it starts,'' said a corporation spokeswoman, Janel Patterson.
 The question is, more quickly than planners plan?

HEADLINE: Jennie Koch, Jason Easterly

 BODY:
Jennie Margaret Koch, the daughter of June Quint Koch and Noel Clinton Koch of Rockville, Md., was married last evening to Jason Tighe Easterly, a son of Patricia Cawthorne Easterly and Dr. Harry Watkey Easterly III of Sturbridge, Mass. Rabbi Arthur Blecher officiated at the Old Angler's Inn in Potomac, Md. 
 The bride, 35, works at the White House as the executive assistant to Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser. The bride is also a major in the Army and a graduate of West Point. She received a master's degree in politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford University, which she attended as a Rhodes scholar. 
 Her father, who was a deputy assistant secretary of Defense in the Reagan administration, is president of TranSecur, a company in Potomac that provides alerts on international security matters to subscribers. Her mother, who also worked in the Reagan administration, as an undersecretary for intergovernmental relations in the Housing and Urban Development Department, is an international consultant for construction and energy projects in the former Soviet Union.
 The bridegroom, 36, is an assistant commonwealth's attorney for Richmond, Va. He graduated from Bowdoin College and received a law degree from the University of Richmond. His father is a general and vascular surgeon on the staff of Harrington Memorial Hospital in Southbridge, Mass.
 Major Koch and Mr. Easterly met last June on a dating Web site, which they visited at the urging of friends and relatives. Major Koch, who is used to 15-hour workdays, did not have much time for dating. (She said her office's unofficial motto is ''Work like a dog, live like a monk.'') And although Mr. Easterly had dated a few women after a long-term relationship, he said he had not met anyone special. 
 His first e-mail message to her set him apart from others who had written her, she said. She enjoyed how it poked gentle fun at a spelling error in her personal profile, demonstrating his attention to detail and sense of humor, she remembered. Soon they were corresponding several times a day, which led to phone calls and a first date in July. 
 With Major Koch's job, Mr. Easterly might have expected to undergo some sort of security check. He did not. But when he arrived unexpectedly at her office in October, he faced the intense scrutiny of her colleagues. (He passed with high marks, Major Koch said.) 
 That evening he proposed to her on the White House grounds.

LENGTH: 1834 words

HEADLINE: Growing Hub for All Things Salvadoran

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER. 
E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IT was business as usual on a recent morning at the Consulate of El Salvador in Brentwood. The television blared in Spanish. Five different local Spanish-language newspapers were being perused in the waiting room, where dozens of Salvadorans sat quietly on plastic chairs waiting to get their passports renewed. Signs posted in Spanish listed the fees: $60 for a passport; $5 for a birth or death certificate. 
 Jose Eduardo Aparicio, 40, of Hempstead, a busboy at the Lucky Dog restaurant in Garden City South, didn't mind the wait for his passport renewal. He had an appointment the following day with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, hoping to get the green card that would enable him to return legally to the United States after what he said would be his first visit to his mother in El Salvador since he came to the Island 20 years ago.
 Next to Mr. Aparicio were Miguel Angel Cruz, 70, a factory worker, and his wife, Emilia Cruz, 57, of Westbury. Mr. Cruz, a resident alien, needed his passport renewed so he could arrange to have his Social Security check sent to El Salvador, where he hoped to retire soon. Mr. Cruz has been in the United States for 18 years; his wife joined him five years ago after raising their two daughters alone in El Salvador. 
 Mariza Angel, 24, drove to the consulate from Flushing, Queens, with her son, Moises, 8, to renew his passport. After being raised by Ms. Angel's mother in El Salvador since he was nine months old, Moises came to live with Ms. Angel, a manicurist, four months ago. She said she needed valid identification for Moises to get him health insurance. 
 ''This is more convenient,'' said Ms. Angel, who chose to drive to the consulate in Brentwood, the only foreign consulate on the Island, rather than take a train to the Salvadoran mission in Manhattan. 
 About 200 people a day come to the consulate to have passports issued and renewed, register marriages, births and deaths, take care of their pensions or appoint a representative to do legal work for them in El Salvador.
 But in the two years since the office moved to Brentwood from East Garden City, it has become much more than a convenient place to process paperwork. In this former bank office Salvadorans can also find legal, tax and immigration assistance, work toward a high school diploma, open a bank account, apply for health insurance, join the Girl Scouts or act in a play. Much of the activity is the work of Luis Montes Brito, the consul general, who is trying to turn the building into the center of community life for Salvadorans on the Island.
 Once a month on Friday nights, Mr. Montes Brito pushes the waiting-area chairs to one side to make room for a stage for a Noche Lirica, a free evening of music and poetry. Mr. Montes Brito, a portly 41-year-old industrial engineer on his first diplomatic assignment, is among the performers. He sings. He recites poems. Last month, he hung paper cutout clouds from the ceiling as decorations for a play, ''To the Right of God,'' which drew an audience of 200. In the summer, Mr. Montes Brito said, he plans to move the entertainment to the parking lot to make room for a larger crowd. 
 ''We are the link between El Salvador and the United States,'' Mr. Montes Brito said. ''Our people here, sometimes they lose their culture.'' 
 Local Salvadorans also turn to the consulate for all sorts of practical help. David Renderos, a real estate broker from Uniondale, comes to the consulate a few mornings each week to advise other Salvadorans on buying homes, helping them fill out paperwork and trying to make sure they aren't being taken advantage of when getting mortgages. Two nights a week, Martin Danenberg, a teacher from Islandia, volunteers his time at the consulate helping Salvadorans work toward their high school equivalency diplomas. ''A large part of the community is illiterate,'' Mr. Danenberg said. ''They never learned to write and read. The future of the community is education.''
 Since February representatives of the Brentwood branch of Citibank have been at the consulate on Monday mornings helping Salvadorans to open bank accounts. 
 ''Our people don't know, they don't speak English,'' Mr. Montes Brito said. ''They carry cash instead of putting in the bank, and that is dangerous.'' He added that many Salvadorans were unaware that they could open a bank account without a Social Security number.
 Marilyn Proios, executive director of the Girl Scouts of Suffolk County, sends a Spanish-speaking staff member to the consulate every week to do outreach. ''We have a leader and we are going to start a Daisy troop and Brownies,'' Ms. Proios said. ''We have some older girls interested in it.'' And the first bilingual Girl Scout troop in Suffolk County was formed last month. 
 Mr. Montes Brito said his main mission was simple: By enhancing life for Salvadorans on the Island, he can improve life for people in El Salvador. The Salvadoran community spends $3 billion a year on Long Island, Mr. Montes Brito said, and pays more than $300 million a year in taxes. Additionally, the two million Salvadorans in the United States wire home $2.1 billion a year. 
 ''We only want a better quality of life for our people,'' Mr. Montes Brito said. ''Everything our community needs, we try to provide that.'' 
 To that end, last year Mr. Montes Brito initiated the formation of the Salvadoran American Alliance, an umbrella organization of presidents of Salvadoran groups, including both the Nassau and Suffolk Salvadoran Chambers of Commerce, the Latin American Coalition, the Salvadoran Civic Committee and the American Salvadorans of Long Island. Directors of the alliance visit the consulate daily to help immigrants with legal, immigration, tax and housing advice. 
 The alliance, says its president, Julio C. Hernandez Sr., pushes for scholarships for higher education for Salvadoran youth on the Island, promotes culture and is lobbying elected officials about obtaining drivers' licenses for undocumented immigrants with a taxpayer identification number instead of a Social Security number. 
 Mr. Montes Brito said the Department of Motor Vehicles was losing out on almost $1 million in fees from people who couldn't get a driver's license because they lacked a Social Security number. 
 ''Many people don't have a driver's license so they hit and run,'' Mr. Montes Brito said. ''If they have a driver's license they can be identified.'' 
 Last month, Mr. Montes Brito led a delegation to Albany to talk with legislators about the driver's license issue. Assemblyman Philip Ramos, a Brentwood Democrat, said it was one of the Salvadoran community's first organized lobbying efforts. 
 Mr. Hernandez said gaining political clout was on the agenda. ''Another goal is to get as many people as we can to be naturalized and become citizens and be able to vote,'' he said. 
 Mr. Montes Brito is also encouraging Salvadorans to get involved in the political process. ''Here in Long Island our community has taxation without representation,'' he said. 
 Santiago Reyes, owner of the Restaurant Coma Lapa in Brentwood, is president of the Suffolk Salvadoran Chamber of Commerce, which has 50 businesses. Mr. Reyes is active in the local Republican Party. 
 ''I pray to God every day I want somebody to represent our community,'' said Mr. Reyes, recounting his own American dream story, including a home to call his own, a successful business and a daughter who graduated from college. He predicted that ''in no less than two to three years, a Salvadoran will be running for a good position in the town, the county, the state.'' 
 Mr. Montes Brito said the Salvadoran community had worked hard to satisfy the basic necessities and was ready to assert itself. ''They are going to move into the political arena,'' he said. ''If you watch the other immigrant communities, this is the next step for the Salvadoran community.'' 
 The 2000 census counted 42,500 Salvadorans in Nassau and Suffolk, but Mr. Montes Brito estimated that there are at least 200,000 Salvadorans on the Island, of whom 50,000 have American citizenship, 100,000 have legal status short of citizenship and 50,000 are here illegally. Salvadorans now rival Puerto Ricans as the largest Hispanic group on the Island, he said. 
 He added that about 65 percent of Salvadorans on the Island live in Suffolk County and that about 30 percent of the total reside in Brentwood.
 During his first official meeting with Hispanic leaders on Tuesday, the Suffolk county executive, Steve Levy, said he talked about ''enhancing sensitivity of the county work force to the Hispanic population.'' 
 But asked about illegal Salvadorans, Mr. Levy said he wanted to ''weed out the illegal underground economy that presently exists on the Island. The underground economy is exploitive of the workers themselves and also puts legitimate businesses at a competitive disadvantage.'' 
 ''We should be promoting immigration in a legal fashion and stop ignoring the fact that so many are coming in an undocumented fashion,'' Mr. Levy continued. ''But it is good to see that there is a sense of organization, because that leads to a quicker assimilation into experiencing the American dream.'' 
 Ray Wysolmierski of Farmingville, a leader of a faction of the Sachem Quality of Life group, which organizes regular protests against illegal immigrants, said Salvadorans who had become American citizens could organize and lobby as long as they didn't speak for illegal immigrants.
 ''We certainly don't want to have them speak to a person on behalf of legalizing illegals or anything like that,'' he said. ''Then they are using their citizenship to give credibility to illegality.'' 
 ''If somebody is going to try to advocate on behalf of a person who is going to advocate for illegals, that person should never be allowed to even be a candidate,'' Mr. Wysolmierski said. 
 On Mr. Montes Brito's helping the Salvadorans to organize, Mr. Wysolmierski said the consul general could try to get the community to represent his point of view, but ''the United States government does not accept stuff done by consuls of other countries. They are not making American laws.''
 Last year, Mr. Montes Brito worked to have Sept. 15 declared Central America Day by the Suffolk County Legislature. The consul was one of the organizers of a parade that drew a crowd of 30,000 to celebrate Central American Day and Salvadoran Independence Day in Brentwood. 
 Leopoldo Herrera produces the community's only television program, ''Cita Con El Salvador'' or ''Proud Salvadorans,'' which appears Saturdays at noon on Cablevision in Nassau and Suffolk. The hourlong program is split between features and sports from El Salvador and stories about Salvadorans succeeding in the United States. Mr. Herrera said that because of the consul general, the Salvadoran leadership on the Island is awakening. 
 ''He wants the community to grow with the system, to get to know the system and deal with the United States,'' Mr. Herrera said.

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 8A; Column 1; Sports Desk; Pg. 7; BASEBALL PREVIEW 2004

LENGTH: 2698 words

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:

THE NATIONAL LEAGUE team capsules were written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish.

N.L. EAST

ATLANTA BRAVES
Bobby Cox, 15th season
2003: 101-61, first place, lost in division series
 Is this the year? Last year was supposed to be, but it wasn't. Several days after the All-Star Game the Braves had a lead in double digits and didn't look back. When the so-called race ended, they had their 12th consecutive division championship.
 But once again the Braves are believed to be vulnerable. Greg Maddux is gone, completing the turnover of the starting rotation. Javy Lopez, the best-hitting catcher in the team's history, is gone. Gary Sheffield, who hit 39 homers and drove in 132 runs last year, is gone too, all victims of the same payroll problems less wealthy teams have.
 Bobby Cox, however, has confounded the experts before, and this year he will try to do it with youngsters like Adam LaRoche, Mark DeRosa and J.D. Drew. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Drew, Eli Marrero, John Thomson, Antonio Alfonseca, Chris Reitsma
 KEY LOSSES -- Maddux, Sheffield, Lopez, Vinny Castilla, Robert Fick, Jason Marquis, Shane Reynolds.
 KEY TO SEASON -- Russ Ortiz and Mike Hampton will have to play the roles of Maddux and Tom Glavine in leading the new corps of starters.

PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES
Larry Bowa, fourth season
2003: 86-76, third place
 Instead of winning the division last year, as many expected, the Phillies finished 15 games behind the Braves. Getting Jim Thome and Kevin Millwood wasn't enough. So this winter they fortified themselves further, obtaining Billy Wagner to replace Jose Mesa as the closer, Tim Worrell and Roberto Hernandez to bolster the bullpen and Eric Milton for the starting rotation.
 They also got themselves a new park, blowing up the old one and hoping their losing experience of the past decade went with it. Pat Burrell hopes his .209 batting average from last year and memories of it went up in smoke, too. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Wagner, Milton, Tim Worrell, Hernandez
 KEY LOSSES -- Mesa, Mike Williams, Brandon Duckworth, Terry Adams
 KEY TO SEASON -- The Phillies need everyone to stay healthy and perform to expectations to slay the beast known as the Braves.

FLORIDA MARLINS
Jack McKeon, second season
2003: 91-71, wild card, won World Series
 The 1997 World Series champion Marlins never got the chance to defend their title. They were dismantled almost before the final out was recorded. These World Series champions have shed some players, too, but the demolishment wasn't nearly as severe.
 The missing are primarily the big run producers: Juan Encarnacion (94 R.B.I.), Derrek Lee (92), Ivan Rodriguez (85). But they retained Mike Lowell (105 R.B.I.). More important, they have held onto their good young pitchers, Josh Beckett, Dontrelle Willis, Brad Penny. 
 But last year they used two closers, Braden Looper and Ugueth Urbina, and both are gone. In their place is Armando Benitez, who throws hard but has a penchant for giving up big home runs. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Benitez, Hee Seop Choi, Darren Oliver
 KEY LOSSES -- Rodriguez, Urbina, Lee, Encarnacion, Mark Redman, Looper
 KEY TO SEASON -- Beckett, Willis and friends will have to be dominant if the Marlins are to have a chance to do what they couldn't do in 1998.

MONTREAL EXPOS
Frank Robinson, third season
2003: 83-79, fourth place
 How long can the Expos trade away their best players and remain a contender for at least part of the season? Vladimir Guerrero and Javier Vazquez are the latest to leave, and the Expos can't expect to be as good without them.
 The middle infielders, Jose Vidro and Orlando Cabrera, could be gone after this season, if not before. The picture remains bleak. 
 They will again play 22 games in Puerto Rico, and their future remains uncertain. They conceivably could be back in Montreal next season, contrary to assurances of baseball officials.
 In the meantime, Frank Robinson will urge his players to ignore everything else and just play the games, winning as many as they can. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Carl Everett, Nick Johnson, Tony Batista
 KEY LOSSES -- Guerrero, Vazquez, Michael Barrett, Orlando Hernandez
 KEY TO SEASON -- The newcomers, Johnson and Everett, have to make up for Guerrero's absent offense and join Vidro and Cabrera in leading the offense.

METS
Art Howe, second season
2003: 66-95, last place
 One of these years the Mets will get it right, but that doesn't mean it will be this year. They just hope the acquisition of Mike Cameron, Kazuo Matsui, Karim Garcia and Braden Looper will do more for them than the addition of Mo Vaughn, Roberto Alomar, Roger Cedeno and Jeromy Burnitz two years ago.
 The defense will be better up the middle with Cameron in center and Matsui and Jose Reyes in the middle infield, though the shortstop and second baseman have not played an inning together this spring. When Vance Wilson catches, it will be even better. But if Wilson is catching, that means Mike Piazza will be playing first base and that won't improve anything. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Matsui, Cameron, Looper, Garcia, Todd Zeile, Shane Spencer, Scott Erickson, Tyler Yates
 KEY LOSSES -- Vaughn, Jay Bell, Tony Clark, Pedro Astacio, Timo Perez
 KEY TO SEASON -- If Tom Glavine makes a vast improvement on his disappointing 9-14 record, he could lead a resurgence, but the Mets will also need help from the weak back end of the rotation.

N.L. CENTRAL

HOUSTON ASTROS
Jimy Williams, third season
2003: 87-75, second place
 There figures to be no more exciting division race than this one. Astros and Cubs. Cubs and Astros. Take your pick. 
 Tied for first with three games to go, the Astros finished a game behind the Cubs last year. The Astros lost two of three to Milwaukee; the Cubs won two of three from Pittsburgh. That's how close it was. The Astros go into this season with two new pitchers by way of New York, Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens, giving them one of the best starting corps, if not the best, in the majors. They also have starters to spare. They traded the 15-game winner Jeriome Robertson and have Carlos Hernandez and Brandon Duckworth in waiting in case someone gets hurt. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Pettitte, Clemens
 KEY LOSSES -- Billy Wagner, Robertson, Geoff Blum
 KEY TO SEASON -- If Octavio Dotel is effective as Billy Wagner's replacement as closer, the Astros will be right there again.

CHICAGO CUBS
Dusty Baker, second season
2003: 88-74, first place, lost in N.L.C.S.
 Maybe Dusty Baker will make the difference, as he has in the past. His contribution, however he does it, cannot be overlooked.
 Maybe it will be Sammy Sosa. Maybe this will be the year he supplants Barry Bonds as the league's most valuable player.
 Or maybe it will be the pitching rotation, with the addition of Greg Maddux, the mesmerizing veteran, to a staff of hard throwers led by Kerry Wood and Mark Prior. Prior opens the season on the disabled list with an inflamed Achilles' tendon and back spasms. That sort of thing, injury, may be the only thing that keeps the Cubs from a shot at the World Series that they squandered last year. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Maddux, Derrek Lee, Michael Barrett, Todd Walker, LaTroy Hawkins 
 KEY LOSSES -- Eric Karros, Damian Miller, Kenny Lofton, Randall Simon
 KEY TO SEASON -- If the pitchers stay healthy, there's no telling how far the Cubs can go, whether or not they win the division championship.

ST. LOUIS CARDINALS
Tony LaRussa, ninth season
2003: 85-77, third place
 Usually a solid contender, the Cardinals may be slipping. They have some players coming back from injuries (Ray Lankford, Jim Edmonds, Chris Carpenter), and they have some shaky positions (left field, second base).
 They also have Reggie Sanders, who is playing for his seventh different team in seven seasons. That's a lot of apartment hunting. 
 Having traded Tino Martinez to Tampa Bay, they have moved the productive Albert Pujols to first base. Last season Pujols batted .359, hit 43 homers and knocked in 124 runs. He fell four home runs short of leading the league, but he did lead in average, hits, runs, doubles and total bases.
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Jason Marquis, Jeff Suppan, Sanders, Lankford, Tony Womack, Marlon Anderson
 KEY LOSSES -- Martinez, J.D. Drew, Eli Marrero, Fernando Vina, Jeff Fassero
 KEY TO SEASON -- To keep up with the pitching-rich Astros and Cubs, the Cardinals need to keep everyone healthy and productive.

CINCINNATI REDS
Dave Miley, second season
2003: 69-93, fifth place
 The homecoming of Ken Griffey Jr. was not supposed to be like this. One injury after another has kept Griffey from enjoying his return home and helping the Reds go somewhere in the division. At this point, even if Griffey is healthy all season, the Reds are not going anywhere.
 It is difficult to go anywhere without pitching. Danny Graves was moved from the closer's role to the starting rotation last season but is the closer again.
 Brandon Larson was supposed to be back at third base after failing in his first trial last season. (He batted .101 in three visits.) But he has an injured toe and is on the disabled list.
 KEY ADDITION -- Cory Lidle
 KEY LOSSES -- Jose Guillen, Scott Sullivan, Chris Reitsma
 KEY TO SEASON -- If Griffey is healthy, he could inspire the Reds to finish first in the lower half of the division.

PITTSBURGH PIRATES
Lloyd McClendon, fourth season
2003: 75-87, fourth place
 The Pirates and the Brewers are locked in a tight race. Each has played 11 consecutive losing seasons, and now they will fight it out for last place in their 12th consecutive losing seasons. Over the first 11 the Brewers 
 (768-943, .449) lead the Pirates (763-951, .445) by 6 games.
 This year's Pirates are a collection of journeyman players -- Chris Stynes (this is his fifth team in five years), Raul Mondesi (third team in three years) and Randall Simon (he started last season with the Pirates and was traded to the Cubs) -- and the untested youngsters -- outfielders Jason Bay and Tike Redman and infielders Jose Castillo and Bobby Hill. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Stynes, Simon, Rick Reed, Jose Mesa
 KEY LOSSES -- Reggie Sanders, Pokey Reese, Matt Stairs, Jeff Suppan
 KEY TO SEASON -- Teams like the Pirates have to be satisfied with small advances. The goal should be to win more games for the third consecutive season.

MILWAUKEE BREWERS
Ned Yost, second season
2003: 68-94, last place
 Richie Sexson slugged 45 homers and drove in 124 runs for the Brewers last season, but the numbers don't begin to define his value to them. This year's starting lineup does.
 The Brewers traded Sexson to Arizona, and their lineup for the start of this season includes four players and a starting pitcher they received in the trade: three fourths of the infield -- Lyle Overbay, Junior Spivey, Craig Counsell -- catcher Chad Moeller and pitcher Chris Capuano. Pitcher Jorge De La Rosa is the only player in the trade who hasn't won a spot. 
 Maybe someone else's players will help. Their own haven't.
 KEY ADDITIONS Counsell, Spivey, Ben Grieve, Gary Bennett, Adrian Hernandez, Overbay, Moeller, De La Rosa, Capuano
 KEY LOSSES Sexson, Royce Clayton, Glendon Rusch
 KEY TO SEASON Even if the newcomers put a spark into them, the Brewers aren't going very far with their pitching.

N.L. WEST

SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS
Felipe Alou, second season
2003: 100-61, first place, lost in division series
 Three shoulder operations kept closer Robb Nen out of action last season and appear to have him unprepared to start this season on time. Last season Tim Worrell replaced Nen and did a commendable job, gaining 38 saves. But this season Worrell is pitching out of the Phillies' bullpen.
 All right, what about Joe Nathan? He did a terrific job last year as Worrell's setup man. Only problem is Nathan now pitches for the Twins. That leaves Matt Herges as the closer until Nen is ready.
 Most people, though, won't be focusing on the closer. Their attention will be riveted on Barry Bonds, the six-time M.V.P.
 KEY ADDITIONS -- A.J. Pierzynski, Dustan Mohr, Michael Tucker, Brett Tomko
 KEY LOSSES -- Rich Aurilia, Benito Santiago, Sidney Ponson, Worrell, Nathan 
 KEY TO SEASON -- They have to ignore the steroids fuss, and they can't afford to go too long without Jason Schmidt (sore shoulder).

SAN DIEGO PADRES
Bruce Bochy, 10th season
2003: 64-98, last place
 For a team that has won a total of only 130 games the past two years, the Padres look pretty good. A bench deeper than most enhances their appearance. Terrence Long and Jeff Cirillo have been regular starters elsewhere but will now serve as backups. 
 Long, who was Oakland's center fielder, will play behind Ryan Klesko, Jay Payton and Brian Giles. Rey Ordonez was supposed to be on the team but didn't want to play behind a rookie shortstop, Khalil Greene. Cirillo will back up Phil Nevin and Sean Burroughs at the corners.
 David Wells is on hand not to serve as a role model for the young pitchers but an example of how to win. And closer Trevor Hoffman is healthy. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Ramon Hernandez, Payton, Long, Wells, Sterling Hitchcock, Ismael Valdez
 KEY LOSSES -- Mark Kotsay, Jesse Orosco, Gary Matthews Jr., Gary Bennett
 KEY TO SEASON -- If Wells leads and the young pitchers follow, the Padres could be the surprise of the league.

LOS ANGELES DODGERS
Jim Tracy, fourth season
2003: 85-77, second place
 Jim Tracy said it was challenging last year to watch his team allow the fewest runs in the majors but also score the fewest. It also had to be frustrating. That the Dodgers finished second demonstrated the importance of pitching.
 Most of the pitchers are back, but unfortunately so are the hitters. The Dodgers acquired Juan Encarnacion, who drove in 94 runs for Florida, but they were inactive for the most part because they were in the process of being sold. The one pitcher who isn't back is Kevin Brown. In his place is Jeff Weaver, who was a disaster with the Yankees. It doesn't figure to be a good swap.
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Encarnacion, Weaver, Rick White, Jeremy Giambi, Olmedo Saenz
 KEY LOSSES -- Brian Jordan, Brown, Paul Quantrill, Fred McGriff
 KEY TO SEASON -- They have to figure out a different way to score runs from the one they used last season. They can't expect the pitching to be as effective as it was.

ARIZONA DIAMONDBACKS
Bob Brenly, fourth season
2003: 84-78, third place
 It was fun while it lasted, having Randy Johnson and Curt Schilling in the starting rotation. They won a World Series a few years ago, which is all the Diamondbacks wanted. But now they have to pay for their economic excesses, and Schilling is gone. Johnson could follow if the team isn't in contention in a few months.
 Shane Reynolds and Steve Sparks won't replace Schilling, but Richie Sexson, who whacked 45 homers and knocked in 124 runs for the Brewers, will provide much needed offensive punch. The Diamondbacks also look forward to a full season from Alex Cintron, their young shortstop, who batted .317 in 117 games last season. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Sexson, Roberto Alomar, Brent Mayne, Reynolds, Sparks 
 KEY LOSSES -- Schilling, Craig Counsell, Junior Spivey, Chad Moeller, Lyle Overbay
 KEY TO SEASON -- It might be time for the hitters to take over from the pitchers and lead the way, but the way could be shaky. 

COLORADO ROCKIES
Clint Hurdle, third season
2003: 74-88, fourth place
 No one can say the Rockies have lost their way because they have never had a way. Once upon a time they won the wild-card spot in the playoffs, but in the last six years, they have finished fourth or fifth and have changed strategies a few times.
 They appeared to be headed in the right direction by developing their own pitchers, but the only home-grown starter is Jason Jennings, who tumbled from a 16-8 record to 12-13. One of the nonnatives is Scott Elarton, a once bright prospect in the Houston organization who has struggled to overcome a shoulder problem. A 4-4 record last year was a start. 
 KEY ADDITIONS -- Vinny Castilla, Jeromy Burnitz, Royce Clayton, Jeff Fassero, Shawn Estes, Joe Kennedy
 KEY LOSSES -- Ronnie Belliard, Juan Uribe, Jay Payton, Chris Stynes, Darren Oliver, Mark Hendrickson
 KEY TO SEASON -- The Rockies keep changing the appearance of their team, and the results are the same.

BYLINE: By Margo Nash with Robert Strauss

 BODY:

Remembering a Revolution
 On Feb. 24, 1969, a group of Rutgers students took over Conklin Hall at the Newark campus. They draped a banner from the roof, renamed the building Liberation Hall and demanded greater diversity throughout the university. 
 The action, which lasted 72 hours, was led by the Black Organization of Students. It set in motion events that eventually increased the number of black students and faculty, and created minority-oriented academic programs. 
 Rutgers has recently been honoring the student leaders of the protest with a plaque in Conklin Hall and an exhibition at the Dana Library, ''Student Activism on the Rutgers-Newark Campus: 1968-1972.'' The show commemorates the Conklin Hall takeover in photographs, signs, leaflets, buttons and other memorabilia. It also chronicles the role Rutgers students played in other demonstrations of the era, like the Vietnam Moratorium Day protests in 1969 and 1970.
 Last week Rutgers graduates who took part in some or all of these protests returned to the Newark campus to participate in a symposium that accompanied the opening of the exhibition. 
 The show was curated by Michael Immerso, 54, a cultural historian and 1972 Rutgers graduate who helped lead the Conklin Hall takeover. Mr. Immerso, author of ''Newark's Little Italy: The Vanished First Ward'' (Rutgers University Press, 1997), said the Conklin Hall student occupation showed that a student protest could ''forge social change.''
 Richard L. McCormick, president of Rutgers, commented about the student protests when the plaque at Conklin Hall was put up last February.
 ''Rutgers had not caused the fundamental racial and economic inequalities that characterized American life, but prior to Feb. 24, 1969,'' he said, according to a university transcript of his speech, ''neither had Rutgers done very much to address those inequalities. These young men and women wanted Rutgers to serve them and their communities, too, and they were right.'' The exhibition is on view through April 30. After that, the material in it will become a special collection at the library. Information on the show: (973)353-5222.

After the Play
 ''Hamlet'' has inspired playwrights from Tom Stoppard, whose 1967 play ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead'' took a closer look at two minor characters in Shakespeare's play, to Pavel Kohout, whose 1977 ''Poor Murderer'' was about a Russian actor who goes mad playing Hamlet.
 But Lee Blessing, head of the playwriting program at the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers in New Brunswick, says the only sequel to ''Hamlet'' is his widely produced 1991 play ''Fortinbras.'' The dark comic work gets its title from the Prince of Norway, who is the last character to speak in ''Hamlet.''
 ''Fortinbras'' is being produced by the Rutgers Theater Company at the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick from Friday through April 18. Mr. Blessing said he was delighted about the production and hoped it would be an opportunity for his students ''to know me better,'' and to come away saying, ''Oh yeah, I guess he can write.'' Information: (732)932-7511.

An Early Great
 A Honus Wagner baseball card, said to be among the most valuable of that kind of collectible, is the focus of a TNT movie, ''The Winning Season,'' making its premiere tonight at 8. The movie, a story of a boy's flight back in time to the 1909 World Series to befriend Mr. Wagner, one of baseball's greats, is based on ''Honus & Me,'' by Dan Gutman, of Haddonfield. Mr. Gutman has written a series of novels for teenagers, many on sports subjects. They include ''The Kid Who Became President'' and ''Babe & Me.''
 ''The Winning Season'' stars Matthew Modine as Mr. Wagner and Kristen Davis (''Sex and the City'') as his love interest. It is directed by John Kent Harrison. Shawn Hatosy plays the teenager who gets to meet his hero and find the secret of the rare baseball card. Margo Nash with Robert Strauss


CORRECTION-DATE: April 18, 2004

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Jersey Footlights column on April 4 about an exhibition at Rutgers University commemorating the 1969 student takeover of Conklin Hall misstated the involvement of Michael Immerso, a 1972 Rutgers graduate who is the curator of the exhibition. Mr. Immerso helped organize a vigil in support of the students; he did not help lead the takeover.

SECTION: Section 5; Column 1; Travel Desk; Pg. 3; TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT
