HEADLINE: Where Travelers Go To Book Online

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI

 BODY:
WHILE online travel agencies like Expedia, Travelocity and Orbitz have marketed extensively to consumers in the past year, many Internet bookers have remained loyal to the individual Web sites of their favorite airlines, hotels and car rental agencies, according to PhoCusWright, a travel industry research and consulting firm. Other firms, like Forrester Research and ComScore Networks, have recorded similar findings. But some analysts believe the supplier sites still have far to go to achieve the quality of the e-travel agencies. 
 Of the roughly $39 billion spent online by leisure travelers last year, half went to the Web sites of individual travel suppliers, according to PhoCusWright, with the biggest three e-travel agencies garnering the rest. The supplier-agency split has remained steady over the past two years, said Lorraine Sileo, an analyst with PhoCusWright. 
 Overall, PhoCusWright says that 26 percent of airline industry sales in 2003 took place online, with 58 percent of those purchases made on the airlines' own sites. Twenty-five percent of all rental car bookings were made online, with 57 percent coming from the rental agency sites. Thirteen percent of all hotel bookings in 2003 came through the Web -- half through the hoteliers' sites.
 Even though the suppliers attract far fewer monthly visitors (for example, in January, Orbitz received 16.15 million visitors compared with 6.4 million at Southwest.com, the most popular airline site, according to ComScore Media Metrix, an Internet research firm), they are competing well for traveler dollars, Ms. Sileo said. ''The push and pull between the online travel agencies and the suppliers' sites is a healthy thing,'' Ms. Sileo said. ''It means the agencies aren't going away, and the suppliers can also reap the rewards of being online. And for both of them, the sites just get better and better.''
 While that may be true, the suppliers' sites could still do a much better job, according to a January study by the market research firm Shelley Taylor & Associates. The firm reviewed 46 travel Web sites in the United States and abroad, and judged them based on a number of criteria, such as how many clicks it takes to complete certain tasks like booking and local restaurant recommendations and general travel tips for a given area, for instance. The firm found that all the sites are ''guilty of failing to deliver satisfying travel experiences.''
 Shelley Taylor, the report's author, said the popularity of supplier sites belied their quality -- or lack thereof. ''With travel agents, you'd get a packet for your trip, with tickets and maps, and then they'd tell you about great restaurants to visit,'' she said. ''Travel sites are not approximating what you can get in the bricks-and-mortar world.'' She noted that Southwest ranked 11th of 13 airline sites tested. Among other things, she said Southwest offered ''very few travel resources'' like destination guides, maps and so on that sites like Expedia.com include. Ms. Taylor also said that because Southwest.com did not have a booking engine on the home page, users must waste clicks searching for it.
 Ms. Taylor's rankings prompted a sharp defense from Southwest, whose Web site has been recognized for above-average performance by other reviewers. Anne Murray, Southwest's senior director of interactive marketing, said the company chose not to include a booking engine on the home page, instead showing a photo of Southwest employees. 
 ''I've had people tell us we're nuts for doing that, but we want to represent the faces of our company first, before we say 'Go buy something,''' Ms. Murray said.
 Ms. Murray agreed with Ms. Taylor's contention that the Web site offers less-intensive destination information than full-service travel agency sites. ''But we're more focused on what our customers want to see next,'' she said. ''Very few customers are asking for things like weather, maps and guides. So many other sites do that.''
 Apart from the Southwest.com criticism, the report offered some good news for American Internet users, in that the top five travel sites were United States based. Expedia topped the rankings, followed by Travelocity, Hilton.com, Orbitz and Continental.com.
 ''We generally chose better sites as part of our sample,'' Ms. Taylor said. ''So being the worst of the best does not mean the worst. It simply means that the entire industry has a very long way to go.''

HEADLINE: Filling in the Bald Spots of a Historic District

BYLINE: By JAKE MOONEY

 BODY:
They designated the area a historic district, and then they went back at it again.
 To the relief of a vocal crowd of residents, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously last week to expand the Murray Hill Historic District in the East 30's, turning what has been an archipelago of preservation into a solid historic zone characterized by low-rise 19th-century row houses.
 The vote, greeted by a chorus of ''thank you's,'' came a little more than two years after the commission first bestowed the historic designation on three chunks of the neighborhood. Preservationists and members of the Murray Hill Neighborhood Association, who feared that this original layout of the historic zone would permit high-rise development in the undesignated sections, were delighted. 
 Although the change still requires approval of the City Planning Commission and the City Council, the day had its drama. Kenneth Turrisi, a Long Island-based architect who owns three adjacent buildings on East 36th Street -- Nos. 126, 128 and 130 -- that would be added to the district, said at the meeting that the expansion would prevent him from building on the land and cause him ''severe economic hardship.'' 
 Mr. Turrisi, who bought two of the lots after they were left out of the original historic district, had twice applied to the Buildings Department to put up a 14-story building on the site, but was denied. He called the expansion ''the Murray Hill neighborhood's thinly veiled attempt to use the landmarks commission to protect their views,'' and his lawyer, Howard Zipser, argued that the buildings showed little historic character. 
 In contrast, supporters of the expanded historic district called it an oasis among Midtown's high-rises. The neighborhood, which lies just west of the entrance to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, greets commuters in the morning and says goodnight in the evening, they said. 
 Before voting to approve the plan, the commission's members said the expansion protected the character of a unique neighborhood, giving the district a needed cohesion. Neighborhood association members cheered, and Mr. Turrisi left quietly. JAKE MOONEY

HEADLINE: In the Art Business, 44,210 Points Makes Polke a Top Painter

BYLINE: By ANDRAS SZANTO. 
Andras Szanto is deputy director of the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
THE first version of art history is written by dealers. They work on the front lines, making bets on artists and objects long before collectors, critics and curators decide what's truly valuable. 
 To offer a glimpse into this rarefied world, the Getty Research Institute has mounted a small but engrossing exhibit titled ''The Business of Art: Evidence From the Art Market.'' Consisting of 81 documents spanning 450 years, the show has no intention of covering its subject encyclopedically. Instead, the curators, Maria L. Gilbert and Mark Henderson, have assembled an eclectic array of ephemera from the Getty's archives to illustrate how values have been assigned to art through history.
 Among the items is a 1939 exclusive contract between the Parisian dealer Ambroise Vollard and the painter Georges Rouault; a ledger of ''sales,'' ''bargains'' and ''deals'' by a 19th-century British collector who invented the steel pen nib; a haunting set of letters documenting how the Nazis forced sales by an art dealer in The Hague; and a colorful 1982 German board game in which players compete for art-world recognition, with the winner receiving this guidance: ''From now on you can afford (practically) anything, your glory seems to be secured, your posthumous glory is merely a question of your inevitable demise (probably soon).'' 
 For the Research Institute, housed in a circular building adjacent to the Getty Museum, the show is an attempt to foster more scholarly interest in the social dynamics of art. It's part of a yearlong project drawing on the work of resident scholars, a conference on art-dealing and a new research partnership on the history of collecting with the University of Southern California.
 ''We see this as part of the total fabric of understanding the history of art,'' said Tom Crow, director of the Research Institute. To focus only on artists and masterpieces, he said, would be ''like listening to one side of a telephone conversation.'' As the documents show, in addition to dealers, collectors, artists and critics have also been known to take an active part in the business side of art.
 The profession of art dealing emerged only after the mid-18th century; the commercial art gallery system is barely a century old. Earlier, artists often served as their own agents. At first, they ''charged a fixed rate for the job, as if they were making a pair of shoes,'' Gerald Reitlinger wrote in his classic work, ''The Economics of Taste.'' Eventually, a new idea arose -- that each work of art is unique -- and with it, a new way of doing business.
 A testament to that development is a parched letter with ornate calligraphy, dated 1628, by the Bolognese painter Guido Reni, appealing to his ''most illustrious and honorable patron'' that ''when paintings are of a caliber that they can be given to noble lords as gifts,'' they merit a special price that should reflect ''respect for the artist.'' Reni concludes, ''My paintings -- praise God -- are partially in this category and merit this type of payment.''
 Even after dealers were firmly established, artists still looked after their own financial interests. In 1955, Alexander Calder wrote a letter to a collector for whom he was making a mobile: ''But we said nothing about the price. What do you have in mind?''
 The archival sources present a prosaic view of art history in which hustle and flattery mingle with high-minded aesthetics. An 1810 note by the sculptor Antonio Canova to Napoleon fawns, ''I went to the feet of Your Majesty to offer the homage of my gratitude.'' In 1879 Paul Gauguin, then a 31-year-old stockbroker, relays a business tip to his friend Camille Pissarro about a colleague who might buy two paintings. Gauguin warns that the pictures should be ''as pretty as possible'' because the man ''knows nothing at all about art.'' 
 Even critics got into the fray. In 1963, Clement Greenberg typed a letter to the London dealer John Kasmin giving detailed instructions on how to display Jules Olitski's Color Field paintings, which he had written about favorably in Art International. Greenberg offered advice on everything from the proper framing to the choice of paint for the gallery walls and even scribbled drawings to press his case.
 It is nevertheless the dealers who get the star treatment in this show. Several prime figures of 19th- and 20th-century art history appear -- among them, Peggy Guggenheim and Leo Castelli -- but the leading role fittingly goes to Joseph Duveen, a turn-of-the-century art merchant and lifestyle guru for Gilded Age socialites like the Fricks, the Morgans and the Huntingtons.
 The British-born Duveen was a genius at trading on the aspirations and insecurities of his American clients. He ran a full-service operation. For the right price, he could procure all the trappings for a ready-made Old World aristocratic household, from paintings and sculptures to tapestries and clocks. Working with a Parisian design firm, he undertook extravagant decoration projects like Mrs. Eleanor Elkins Widener Rice's New York town house, where the drawing-room furnishings alone cost $2 million in 1925 (about $20 million today).
 Ambitious, methodical and well connected, Duveen hired an international network of spies and runners to track down clients and artworks for sale. Some of his cloak-and-dagger antics may seem outmoded, but his fingerprints remain all over America's greatest art collections.
 The exhibition is a coming-out party for the recently cataloged Duveen archive, a vast trove of information about the backstage operations of the international art trade. In the Getty's care since 1998, its contents have never been presented to the public. Among the gems is a book bearing the title, ''Things Seen: Homes of Fine Goods.'' It contains typed and handwritten reports used by Duveen's associates -- obtained who knows how -- listing every valuable object inside certain British aristocratic homes.
 The most eye-opening section of the exhibit is a set of documents laying bare Duveen's business dealings with Bernard Berenson, the Renaissance scholar and connoisseur who authenticated Italian old master paintings for Duveen and, in return, received a 10 percent commission (later upgraded to 25 percent), and a retainer. Displayed here is a 1928 contract reaffirming their secret agreement, along with an ''attestation album'' -- a collection of photographic reproductions of Italian paintings, accompanied by Berenson's signed attributions -- which Duveen occasionally presented to clients after a sale.
 Recent efforts to demystify artists' reputations, and their investment potential, by quantitative analysis make up the last section of the Getty show. Among others, it features the charts and computations of Willi Bongard, a maverick German economist whose Kunstkompass newsletter, edited since his death by his widow, has been tracking artists more or less like stocks for three decades. Bongard's index of art-world fame assigns numerical values to various indicators of success -- for example, 800 points for an A-list museum show, 100 points for reviews in certain arts publications. (The top-ranked artist in 2003 was Sigmar Polke, with a score of 44,210.) The annually published results allow art-market speculators to forecast the earnings potential of today's stars. 
 Those calculations should be taken with a grain of salt, of course. As the exhibition makes plain, no amount of research can explain why some artworks fetch millions while most remain worthless. In the words of the economist Michael Hutter, one of the scholars exploring the practical side of art at the Getty, ''You will always have prices and new directions, but what you can't take out is the fabricated mystery that only a very few individuals have the secret knowledge to produce.''

'The Business of Art'
Getty Research Institute Exhibition Gallery, Los Angeles. Through June 13.

HEADLINE: A Boomlet in the Rental Market

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
NEW buildings full of apartments are sprouting all over the county, but perhaps nowhere so visibly as here. Cranes rise over the downtown, as the developer Louis R. Cappelli and others build residential towers in the city's heart, continuing what some have called a huge boom in rental housing construction in Westchester.
 As recently as last year, the owners of these new rental units had been concerned that filling them would be a problem. But today, while the picture is not universally rosy, the rental market seems to be relatively strong, bolstered by a generally tight supply of housing in the county, which has pushed house prices up.
 Next to the Metro-North train station here at Bank Street Commons, which has 500 apartments in two towers, units have been moving fairly well, said Peter Gilpatric, senior vice president for LCOR, the developer. More than half of the apartments have been rented in the last year, with one-bedrooms going for about $1,700 and up and two-bedroom rents starting about $2,500, he said. And while some observers might note that the building could be also described as half empty, Mr. Gilpatric said that however one described it, there were still a sufficient number of tenants to meet LCOR's goals. 
 Last spring, about 26 new apartment leases were being signed a month; since Jan. 1 of this year, that number has increased to more than 35 a month, Mr. Gilpatric said. At Clayton Park, another new luxury apartment complex in this city, Clay Fowler, a principal for Clayton Park Development in Stamford, Conn., said: ''Leasing has met our midlevel expectation. After 9/11 and the economic downturn, we may have readjusted expectations, but we're still more than surviving.''
 About 60 percent of the 260 for-rent studios, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments have been leased, he said.
 Nicholas Wolff, the president of Century 21 Wolff, which deals primarily in sales, agreed that the rental market is doing better than expected. ''Things may not be phenomenal with rentals, but we were very, very nervous that there would be too much inventory and not enough demand,'' he said. ''That isn't the case.''
 Apartment developers reported that while they were offering incentives sometimes, they were not doing it regularly. 
 Westchester's fairly strong rental market appears to be an anomaly compared to the rest of the nation, said Paul Emrath, a housing policy economist for the National Association of Home Builders, a trade organization in Washington. 
 The vacancy rate for rentals in an area including Westchester and New York City, as well as Rockland County and Richmond County on Staten Island, but not on Long Island or in New Jersey, was 4.4 percent in 2003, Mr. Emrath said. For the rest of the country, the vacancy rate for rentals was 9.8 percent, the economist said. Only the Los Angeles region, with a 3.2 percent rate, fared better. 
 There are a number of reasons for this. For one, developers of luxury apartments in Westchester are able to tap the demographics they need. At Bank Street Commons, the largest group of renters includes affluent single men in their 50's, said Karyn Smith, the development's property manager. The other two largest groups are single professionals in their late 20's and 30's and young married professionals. Some work in Manhattan, and others are employed in White Plains or Stamford. Some have moved out of the city, while others have moved from houses or apartments elsewhere in the county, Ms. Smith said.
 The median household income for Westchester was $63,582 in 1999, according to the United States Census Bureau's most recent figures. For the nation, the median was $41,494, the figures showed. Unemployment in Westchester was 4.6 percent in February of this year, compared with 6 percent for the nation and 6.9 percent for New York State, figures from the state show.
 NATIONALLY and locally the clamor has been for home ownership, as opposed to rentals. The nation's rental market, according to David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, has been hurt by low interest rates that have prompted people to buy homes if they can rather than renting, plus a weak job market, which in turned has retarded the formation of new families, the group that often rents before buying a home. In Westchester, however, there has been an added wrinkle, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, chief executive officer of the Westchester County Board of Realtors in White Plains. The for-sale housing market locally ''is fiercely expensive, and there's not that much available,'' he said. Mr. Mercurio could not confirm reports that the rental market was faring better than expected, because the Board of Realtors has limited data on rentals. ''My sense is that the rental market is slower, although that's just a feeling,'' he said.
 The sentiments of Jonathan and Cindy Frieder, tenants at Bank Street Commons, suggest that the state of the for-sale market is a big factor. 
 Mr. Frieder, a technology consultant who works in Manhattan, said: ''I'm certainly not going to pay half a million dollars for a three-bedroom fixer-upper.'' 
 Last year ''may have been a softening year, but it wasn't a devastating one,'' said Paul Crisalli, senior vice president for JPI Apartment Development, a Texas-based company that is building 281 apartments along Mamaroneck Avenue called the Residences at Jefferson. ''There's a misconception out there about what's going on.'' 
 Mr. Crisalli said he is optimistic that his apartments, when they go on the market later this year, will also rent well. JPI has not yet set prices for the apartments.
 Several blocks away along Mamaroneck Ave., the main drag here, Mr. Cappelli, the president of Cappelli Enterprises, is similarly banking on the availability of a well-heeled rental population. 
 Mr. Cappelli has just begun renting luxury apartments in a 311-unit tower called One City Place. His market: young singles, working couples, divorced people and empty-nesters, said Marge Schneider, a vice president for Cappelli Enterprises.
 One couple, empty-nesters with grandchildren in Westchester, rented an apartment at One City Place sight unseen, Ms. Schneider said. ''They wanted a place where they can lock the door and not worry when they're not here,'' she said. Apartments at One City Place range from about $1,400 to more than $4,000, with one of the highest-priced ones a three-bedroom on the 29th floor with a 20-foot-by-30-foot terrace that offers views of the Long Island Sound. 
 Aware also that the sales market is stronger than the rental market, Mr. Cappelli recently scaled back the number of rental units planned for City Center. Rather than build 625 rental apartments in two 32-story towers, Mr. Cappelli decided to build 311 rental units in one tower, and 211 condominiums in the second. A 4,000-square foot, single-story building next to City Center was sold to Mr. Cappelli in mid-February, said Joshua Makanoff, who owned a 50 percent in the building. He would not disclose the sale price of the building, which contains three small shops, including Mr. Makanoff's book store, Main Street Book Shop.
 Elsewhere in the county, the luxury rental market appears to be solid. At Scarsdale Commons, 15 of the 42 apartments starting at $2,700 and going up to $3,700, have been spoken for, even before the advertising campaign has begun, said Joyce Bonhag, director of marketing for the developers, Garson Brothers Development of Bronxville. On Yonkers's waterfront, the 266-unit Hudson Park is being built by the Stamford-based Collins Enterprises. Arthur Collins, a principal in the development and management company, reported that about 75 percent of the first tower and 50 percent of the second are leased in the apartment buildings that opened last year.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk; Pg. 5; POLITICS

LENGTH: 913 words

HEADLINE: Breaking Tradition, 2 Democrats Win Pelham Manor Board Seats

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

DATELINE: PELHAM MANOR 

 BODY:
IN this village's 113-year history, a Democrat has never been elected to serve as a trustee or mayor, the local wisdom goes. (There was one pesky Democrat who was appointed to serve the town around the turn of the century, local Democratic leaders say.) 
 No Democrats were elected, that is, until just a few weeks ago, when two were voted in to the five-member board of trustees. They will be sworn in tomorrow night. 
 The election March 16 has been the talk of the town, with about a third of the registered voters turning out in a snowstorm to vote just for trustees. Afterward, some residents cheered for the change, while others bemoaned the defeat of Lorri Gorman, who had served on town boards and with the trustees for a total of 12 years and was soon to be in line for the mayoralty. 
 Pelham Manor politics have long been guided by the village's ''ladder system,'' which started aspiring office-holders from their first rung of public service, on the planning and zoning boards or in the position of town attorney, and then moved them up the rungs, through the board of trustees and on to mayor. This progressed smoothly, without much need for the electorate, provided everyone on the rungs agreed to be a Republican. (There were two exceptions in recent years: a person with no political affiliation was appointed to the planning board, as was a Democrat, Ms. Gorman said.)
 The two victorious Democrats, Timothy P. Fisher, 56, a tax lawyer, and Steven Flanders, 62, the former circuit executive of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, defeated Ms. Gorman and Val Taubner, who had served on the board of trustees for a year. 
 But Mr. Fisher noted that the Democrats won by only about 40 votes each. 
 ''A number of new residents have moved in who are not necessarily tied in to any group of people,'' he said, explaining the victory. ''They weren't committed to a system that's been around for a hundred years.''
 There are a number of other possible explanations for their success. In recent years more Democrats in this square-mile village have been willing to run for office, which was not always the case. (This was Mr. Flanders's third try, for example.) The victory has also been attributed to the growing number of Democrats in town, the qualifications of the two winning candidates, the hard work of the candidates' campaign organizations and voters' desire for change -- not to mention the suggestion that one component of the vote was simply a protest against ever-rising taxes that somehow managed to make history in this small village that borders on the north Bronx. 
 At the Four Corners shopping area, at Pelhamdale Avenue and Boston Post Road, opinions about the election were mixed a week or so after the election. 
 ''I'm really surprised Lorri Gorman lost,'' said Rita McLaughlin, a resident. ''She's done a lot for the town, and it was a disappointment that she lost.''
 Another resident, Carol Ipsen, who worked on the Democratic campaign, said she believed Mr. Fisher and Mr. Flanders would work for a more democratic system, ''not to destroy but restore.'' 
 But Ms. Gorman, who said she had no plans to run in any future elections, defended the system as a way to pick existing community leaders and train them in how the government runs.
 ''By the time you get to be mayor, you have had your hands in every aspect of management of the village, and each step of the way increases your depth and breadth of knowledge,'' she said.
 She said the local governments in Scarsdale and Rye Brook also did not use national party affiliations in their local elections. 
 Of the former mayors still living around Pelham, half were actually Democrats who had switched parties, Ms. Gorman said, adding that she did not know how many had switched back.
 But Jennifer Ryan Safsel, the chairwoman of the village Democrats, remembers moving here seven years ago and hoping to join the planning board. ''I thought I moved to a more progressive state,'' she said, remembering the requirement to drop her national party affiliation. 
 As for the future of the ladder system, ''there will never again be anyone who changes his or her registration to serve in the ladder system,'' Mr. Flanders predicted, adding that for the first time in a very long time, there would likely be a Democratic candidate for mayor in the next election.
 Ms. Safsel said now that Democrats see a victory is possible, more of them will consider running for office. Mr. Flanders said the ladder system attracted young people who would work hard and move up through the ranks. 
 George Latimer, a county legislator and chairman of the Westchester County Democratic Committee, said one of the new trustees' tasks would be addressing one of the voters' most pressing concerns, high local taxes. ''It takes people who have been out of office to question the assumptions,'' especially in the municipal budget, he said. ''They are much less wedded to the status quo. They didn't create those sets of structures, and are more motivated to challenge them and find economies.''
 Ms. Gorman noted that the trustees had kept annual budget increases down to 3 percent a year for the last five years, and had recently made difficult decisions resulting in $150,000 in budget cuts. 
 Hard work is ahead for the new trustees, Mr. Latimer predicted. ''Having a two-party system doesn't mean nirvana comes the next day,'' he said. ''Now the Democrats have to prove they'll be capable in public office.''

HEADLINE: Novelist Helps a Chechen Hit the Books in America

BYLINE: By MICHELLE YORK

DATELINE: ALFRED, N.Y., March 31 

 BODY:
The story of friendship between two families connected to this small college town includes a war, a spy novelist, an aspiring student, terror, bravery and an international journey.
 It begins in 1993, when Robert Littell, an American writer living in France, refused to allow his oldest son, Jonathan, then 25, to accompany him and other volunteers taking medical supplies to a Croatian camp for Bosnian refugees.
 The younger Mr. Littell was furious. He packed a bag and left his father's home, eventually finding an office for Action Against Hunger in Split, Croatia. He walked in and demanded a job. 
 The Frenchman in the office told the family later that he had been flabbergasted -- partly because Mr. Littell was wearing a suit in a war zone, and partly because of the young man's audacity. But he liked audacity, and hired him. 
 Jonathan Littell then began a life that might have been dreamed up by his father, whose last novel, ''The Company,'' has been sold to Columbia Pictures for movie rights. He traveled throughout Bosnia, and later the Russian republic of Chechnya, taking food to trapped people, and once became trapped himself in a basement in Grozny, the capital, during a Russian attack. 
 In 1999, amid new violence in Chechnya, Jonathan Littell went to neighboring Ingushetia to set up a field office for Action Against Hunger. There he met with Adam Susarov, a Muslim refugee whose family had been continually displaced by Russian-Chechen wars. In him, Mr. Littell found an able security officer and trusted friend.
 The two organized relief missions throughout Chechnya. They knew how to talk their way past border guards and evade local thugs.
 By January 2001, Mr. Littell had enough, and he decided to leave Action Against Hunger. He was two weeks from being replaced when he and his friend Mr. Susarov helped organize a trip with Doctors Without Borders to bring supplies to a hospital south of Grozny. The head doctor warned them it wasn't safe there and agreed to accompany them down back roads to the border. The doctor got in the first car, and Mr. Susarov and Mr. Littell rode in the second. Kenny Gluck of Brooklyn, the regional director of Doctors Without Borders, was in the third car. A fourth driver brought up the rear.
 En route, three gunmen ambushed the convoy. Chechnya had a history of kidnappings, and Americans were particularly prized. Some foreigners had been held for ransom and released. Some had been beheaded. ''Uezhaem!'' said Mr. Littell, speaking Russian for ''Let's go!''
 Mr. Susarov slammed the car back into Mr. Gluck's, then darted forward through a spray of bullets, around the gunmen, his car straddling the ridge of an embankment as they fled.
 Bullets struck Mr. Littell's seat and a tire. Shrapnel sliced an artery in his left temple. But Mr. Littell and Mr. Susarov had escaped. Mr. Gluck was captured and held for nearly a month.
 Jonathan Littell was safe, but his father couldn't help but think he would feel the same terror and anguish as the family of Mr. Gluck, had it not been for the bravery of Mr. Susarov.
 ''As time developed, I said, 'Jon, what can we do for Adam? He risked his life for you.''' 
 They decided to honor Adam Susarov's dream of seeing his oldest son, Akhdan, attend an American university.
 From the beginning, Robert Littell thought of his alma mater, Alfred University, tucked in the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains. He contacted his brother, Alan Littell, who lives near the college, from which he had also graduated and where he worked at as a public relations officer.
 The college president, Charles M. Edmondson, easily remembered Robert Littell. He had read a galley copy of Mr. Littell's last book, offering some suggestions, and was intrigued by idea of helping Akhdan attend Alfred. ''What's more symmetrical than repaying the son of someone who helped your son?'' he asked.
 The Littells paid for Akhdan's English tutors, and agreed to cover all of his living expenses. His grades were high enough to earn a full academic scholarship.
 Then came the task of convincing the United States to grant a visa to the young Muslim for undergraduate study in the wake of Sept. 11. ''Nothing was easy about it,'' Jonathan Littell said in a phone interview. ''Yes, this was for Adam. But it was more than that. I handed out flour and sugar, and that helped people. But it didn't change their lives. This was a chance to change one person's life, so he'd have an opportunity that he wouldn't have had.''
 Late last year, the United States granted Akhdan, now 21, a visa. He flew here in time for the winter semester and is studying biology, English and economics. His future career is uncertain, though he knows he wants to help rebuild Chechnya, and an American degree will help him. 
 Like any freshmen, he's learning to navigate his way, not just around campus but through American culture. Co-ed dorms were a shock; expressions like ''How are you doing?'' a puzzlement. He's made some friends, including some who speak Russian, and he calls home once a week. ''He always asks me about my grades, my health, the Littell family,'' Akhdan said of his father. ''In my culture, we don't talk about feelings, but I know he's happy.''
 To help thank the university, Robert Littell flew from France to conduct a writer-in-residence workshop at Alfred this week. 
 When he wasn't in class, he was usually with Akhdan, delighting in him as if he were his own son.
 He hasn't met Adam Susarov, though he longs to. ''He risked his life to save my son, and he succeeded,'' Robert Littell said. ''There is no way I could repay that. The day we meet, I will embrace him.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert Littell, an author, with Akhdan Susarov on the campus of Alfred University in western New York. Mr. Littell helped Mr. Susarov come from Chechnya. (Photo by Michael J. Okoniewski for The New York Times)
 Jonathan Littell was wounded in an ambush in Chechnya while aiding a medical relief mission.

HEADLINE: THE NEW WORLD OF CUT-RATE FARES

BYLINE: By KATHERINE ZOEPF. 
KATHERINE ZOEPF is a graduate student at the London School of Economics.

 BODY:
ON a recent Saturday morning, an eager young man patrolled the Ryanair check-in lines at Stansted Airport, 34 miles northeast of London, with a clipboard and an amazing offer: sign up for a new credit card, and receive a free one-way return ticket from anywhere in Europe. He wasn't getting any takers. ''Nah, mate,'' one traveler remarked, ''s'only about 3 quid to get back anyway.''
 This is the brave new world of low-cost flying. Since 1997, when the European Union fully deregulated air travel within its borders, carriers like Ryanair, EasyJet and their imitators have been leading a race to the bottom in air ticket pricing, forcing European national carriers to cut costs and lower their ticket prices as well. Over the past several years, the slashed prices have transformed the way Europeans, and particularly those who live near the hubs of the new budget airlines, think about air travel. In Britain these days, brides-to-be on tight budgets may take gaggles of friends to Italy for their hen parties, middle-income families can contemplate buying vacation cottages in France or Spain, and footloose travelers whisk across a continent for about the same price as a bus ticket to the next town.
 Rick Steves, the author of the ''Europe Through the Back Door'' series of travel guides, said that Americans traveling in Europe had been far more cautious than Europeans in embracing the new air-travel mind-set. 
 This may be, as Mr. Steves suggests, because Americans' short vacations don't give them the flexibility to seek out the best fares. Or it may be that Americans don't realize just how low the fares can go. Ryanair tickets from Barcelona to Paris in early April were recently selling for $9.35, at $1.90 to the pound, and SkyEurope tickets from Amsterdam to Budapest in early April were $32, at $1.25 to the euro. 
 Budget airlines keep their costs so very low by turning their planes around again quickly, by requiring travelers to buy online, and by flying into smaller regional airports (though the European Commission declared last month that a deal struck by Ryanair with one of these ''secondary'' airports, Brussels' Charleroi, was illegal, leading some to worry that budget airlines may stop flying to certain state-subsidized secondary airports). The very lowest fares are typically found either by booking long in advance or by waiting for the steeply discounted ''seat filler'' tickets that often become available shortly before a flight, so travelers need to be flexible. 
 Ronel Zeki, 25, a native of Johannesburg who moved to London last summer, said that she and many of her friends have become addicted to checking budget airline Web sites for last-minute deals. She has been to Dublin and Amsterdam already, and she said she would not rule out going someplace she had never heard of if the price was good enough. ''My focus is on traveling and seeing as much of Europe as I can while I'm here,'' Ms. Zeki said. ''And if it's going to cost me the same as getting into a car and driving for an hour, why not go someplace a bit different for the weekend?''
 Sharon Lougher, editor of the fifth edition of Time Out's Europe by Air, said that many Europeans were taking a similarly casual approach to air travel. The guide specializes in suggesting to travelers what they might do once they have bought that cheap ticket, and suddenly find themselves with 36 hours to spend in Haugesund, Norway, say, or Pau, in France. A whole host of small towns that were once nearly unknown outside their regions are now being discovered as whimsical weekend destinations.
 ''When a clutch of new airlines emerged flying to smaller airports (a preferred modus operandi, because it plays a large part in keeping an airline's costs down), we realized that there was a hunger for newly accessible (but more unfamiliar) destinations like Pescara, Esbjerg, Klagenfurt,'' Ms. Lougher wrote in an e-mail message, referring to airports in Italy, Denmark and Austria. ''We published our first guide in 2002, and covered over 80 destinations. Now the guide covers over 140.''
 Ms. Lougher said that Europeans were traveling more, and more frequently, than they ever have before: ''U.K. visits abroad have tripled in the last three years, and have gone up by 10 million in the five years of 1998 and 2002 inclusive. This statistic can largely be attributed to budget airlines, for obvious reasons.'' Yet some travel experts say that Americans planning trips to Europe are just starting to become aware of the ways that they might use Europe's new, no-frills airlines.
 Mr. Steves, the American guidebook writer and a travel consultant, said Americans were skeptical about the low-cost airlines. ''A lot of people want to believe that there's no free lunch in the airline industry,'' he said. ''And to a certain extent, that's true. You need to make sure you make a sober choice. If you save 100 bucks on the flight, and then end up spending hours getting in from the airport, then maybe that's not worth your time. Americans have the shortest vacations in the rich world, and they have to be more focused in their approach.''
 For many Americans, Mr. Steves said, the classic rail tour of Europe, with a backpack and a Eurail Pass, remains the preferred approach. There are some routes, he said, London to Dublin, for instance, where not even Americans take the train anymore. But ''Eurail is making the passes more and more flexible,'' he said. ''For the American market, rail is easily keeping up with air.'' 
 Mr. Steves said that despite his initial fears, the Madrid train bombing had not dented American enthusiasm for riding the rails. ''I've been impressed by how quickly it's been bulldozed to the back of people's minds,'' he said. 
 The 2004 edition of ''Europe Through the Back Door'' includes a section on Europe's low-cost airlines, which advises United States travelers to research air deals carefully, pointing out that flights may land at regional airports as much as 60 miles away from a destination city, or in a different country altogether. (Mr. Steves cites Malmo, Sweden, which is about 45 minutes by airport shuttle bus from Copenhagen.)
 But Carrie Jaecksch, 23, said that though she and a friend bought Eurail Passes for her first trip to Europe, following college graduation a year and a half ago, she wishes she had known that there was a budget-friendly air option. Airlines like Ryanair and EasyJet, she said, ''just aren't very well known in the States.''
 ''Our Europass tickets cost something like $500,'' Ms. Jaecksch said. ''The first time I heard of the low-cost airlines was on that trip, and I was, like, 'What?!''' 
 ''Most of our Eurail experience was night trains, crammed into little smelly compartments with people we didn't know,'' she said. ''It's not like we were even looking out the window and seeing Europe. To console ourselves, we thought, well, maybe you have to be European to get the plane tickets.''
 You do not have to be European. This winter, I decided to test out Ryanair's ultracheap offerings on a weekend trip to Bruges. For purposes of comparison, I planned to return by the quickest and cheapest train route available. 
 In the middle of January, spur-of-the-moment Saturday morning tickets from Stansted to Ostend-Bruges, in Belgium, on Ryanair were selling for $:6.99, or $12.70, about 10 hours before the planned departure. All told, the one-way ticket came to $:24.34, or $44.20, once airport and other taxes had been added. This still seemed like a pretty terrific deal to this (American) traveler. Credit card details were duly tapped in, and a moment later, up popped a message explaining that, as Ryanair was a ticket-free airline, passengers were expected to print up their own confirmation numbers and to take them, along with appropriate photo ID, to check in.
 I arrived at Stansted Airport the next morning via the Stansted Express train from central London, a trip of about 45 minutes. The big, boxlike check-in area was difficult to navigate at first: throngs of passengers carrying overnight bags wandered like lost sheep among acres of tiny, often unstaffed counters. A full 50 minutes before departure, a line was already forming at the gate. Ryanair doesn't make seat assignments, so fans of the exit-row seats (more legroom) arrive early.
 Ryanair and its brethren wear the ''no frills'' epithet with pride. On the Ostend-Bruges flight, there were no airline magazines, no in-flight movies or music, and no baggies of pretzels. Passengers didn't seem to mind: the plane was in the air for exactly 27 minutes, so they scarcely had time to scan their newspapers.
 At Ostend's sleepy airport, where the flight from London was the only one expected for several hours, the 60-odd passengers filed casually off the plane and onto a waiting shuttle bus bound for Bruges proper. Twenty minutes later, they were busy losing themselves in the ancient streets of the medieval town.
 The return trip by train -- Bruges to Brussels to London via Eurostar -- took nearly five hours, and at $149.90, cost close to four times as much as my flight. And yet, of course, people take rail or air journeys for very different reasons.
 ''Train travel has much lower check-in times, and can, in general, get you much closer to the center of a city,'' Ms. Lougher said of ''interrailing,'' or journeys on Europe's rail network. ''In my experience, interrailing and budget airline travel attract two different sorts of people.'' 
 Tim Roebuck, vice president of sales for ACP Rail, a Hoboken-based company that sells Eurail Passes in the United States, also sought to identify the typical Eurail customer as a wholly different ''type'' of traveler. ''They want to meet other people who are traveling around,'' he said. ''You're much closer to the local culture.'' Many American train-pass customers are of college age, he said, but in general they aren't roaming as widely or for as long as their counterparts a generation ago did. ''People aren't doing all 17 countries anymore,'' Mr. Roebuck said of American Eurail customers. ''It used to be the trip of a lifetime, but it's cheaper now. People realize that they can go to Europe several times in a lifetime.''
 But Paul Fitzsimmons, a spokesman for Ryanair, pooh-poohed the idea that train travel was the best way to experience European culture. Budget airlines, he said, are ultimately bringing Europe closer together.
 ''Are we like a bus in the sky? Absolutely,'' he asked. ''Do we want to be a bus in the sky? Absolutely. This is not brain surgery. Nor should it cost you a bank loan.''
 According to Mr. Steves, the guidebook writer, it isn't the low-cost airlines that have changed Europe; it's that Europe itself has changed. ''That vagabond experience in Europe, sleeping on the trains and camping out in youth hostels, has changed now,'' he said. ''You're not hanging around in front of American Express waiting to get your mail anymore, because you've got your cellphone.''
 ''Europe's just not as romantic and misty and exciting as it was when we were kids,'' he said.

HEADLINE: In Bhutan, Mountains, Lamas, and Golf?

BYLINE: By RICK LIPSEY. 
RICK LIPSEY is again covering golf for Sports Illustrated.

 BODY:
TREKKING, watching religious festivals and tasting yak meat and the world's hottest chilies were on the to-do list when my wife, Carrie, and I visited Bhutan, the Himalayan kingdom wedged between Tibet and India, in the fall of 2000. As avid golfers, we also wanted to play on the roof of the world and made a tee-time at Royal Thimphu, a nine-hole layout in the capital, Thimphu, that is Bhutan's only bona fide course. 
 We didn't plan to make history, but we did. Carrie was the first left-handed woman to hit a shot on Bhutanese soil (a shanked 7 iron!), and I became Bhutan's first golf pro.
 While playing with members at Royal Thimphu, I gave my hosts swing tips and they told me the club's dream was to replace Jack Nicklaus videos with a professional teacher. I jokingly said that although not a pro, I'd played college golf, given lessons to friends and was a golf writer for Sports Illustrated. 
 Apparently, the Bhutanese hackers were desperate. ''When could you come?'' the club secretary said deadpan.
 I was shocked. My head whirring like a Buddhist prayer wheel, I looked at Carrie, but she too was nearly hyperventilating. I then glanced at the jaw-dropping surroundings -- the spectacular mountains, the monasteries, rivers, farms, bright prayer flags and soaring eagles -- and said, ''Ummm, well, yes, I'll be your pro.''
 Back in New York, thinking about the adventure was intoxicating. Golf and exploring the Himalayas are my favorite hobbies, and now I'd be a pro in my Xanadu. Some golf instructor friends gave me tutorials that would help me teach the club's 100 members (99 of them male, including the king, a 13-handicapper) and start a junior program. Carrie, a civil rights lawyer, also was gung-ho, because she had lined up work with Bhutan's chief justice to help draft the country's Penal Code and Evidence Act.
 We were to go in fall of the following year for a little over three months. But nine months before our scheduled departure, Carrie became pregnant with our first child. ''No way am I taking a baby to Bhutan,'' Carrie said. Most of our friends reacted similarly, saying, in effect, that bringing an infant to Bhutan would constitute child abuse.
 Like me, though, Carrie has an insatiable appetite for travel, especially in Asia; we had honeymooned in Nepal, and this would be her fourth trip to the continent. So, eventually Carrie's lust for the road overruled the prevalent American paranoia about taking children to any place resembling a National Geographic article's subject, and we decided to go a year later, taking a sabbatical and a maternity leave in the fall of 2002. 
 Upon capitulating, however, she had one non-negotiable demand: ''We ship a full supply of baby gear to Bhutan.''
 To say that Bhutan, a country with one foot in the 21st century and one in the 19th, is different from America is a colossal understatement. Slightly larger than Switzerland but with only about 730,000 citizens, Bhutan has no chain stores or traffic lights, but it does have the highest unclimbed mountain, Gangkar Punsum (24,741 feet). It also measures prosperity with Gross National Happiness, not Gross Domestic Product. 
 Two of every three Bhutanese are farmers, and most still wear the national dress, a gho for men and a kira for women, woven and brightly colored robelike garments. There are no highways and one airport, cut into a deep valley between the mountains, Bhutan didn't officially get the Internet and television until 1999. Cellphones arrived last year, and the first A.T.M. just recently. 
 But golf came to Bhutan 35 years ago. Then, the Tashichhodzong, a sprawling fortlike structure with offices for the country's key government and religious officials, was surrounded by putrid rice paddies. An Indian army officer told King Jigme Singye Wangchuck that he could turn the glop into a manicured lawn by building a golf course. The king was unfamiliar with golf, but he liked the idea of a green oasis, and the course opened a few years later.
 Today, there are similarities and differences between golf in Bhutan and the rest of the world. The biggest differences: the lack of even one motorized cart, and the altitude. In Thimphu (7,500 feet), the ball flies 20 percent farther than at sea level, and yet the course is fairly short at about 5,500 yards and par 66 from the two sets of tees used for an 18-hole round. 
 Another major difference is that golf, and Tiger Woods, are virtually unknown to the Bhutanese except the 130 or so businessmen and officials who play, and I always chuckled when monks and other passers-by peered quizzically through the chain-link fence around the course. 
 At a junior clinic, I asked, ''Who knows Tiger Woods?'' and ''Who knows the Rock?'' Not one of the 35 kids knew Woods, but they all knew the Rock, the World Wrestling Entertainment star. 
 The similarities? If you lifted Royal Thimphu out of its Himalayan environs, the course would resemble an average municipal layout in the United States, except for the large white brick chorten (a religious monument) by the third tee. (The few other courses in the country are more primitive and mainly on military bases.) 
 The Bhutanese also enjoy gambling and mulligans, and there's a gang of golf widows of the first degree, whose husbands spend most evenings in the clubhouse imbibing and eating fried mo mo's (a dumpling) doused in wicked-hot chili sauce while discussing bad shots, the latest clubs and favorite PGA Tour players.
 The Bhutanese also are obsessed with distance. On my first day at work, I taught Brigadier V. Namgyel, head of the Royal Bodyguard. A meaty 6 feet 2 inches and 200 pounds, Namgyel is built like an N.F.L. linebacker, and he swings like one, too. His first question: ''How can I hit the ball farther?''
 The best thing about being Bhutan's first golf pro was that everybody -- including nongolfers -- wanted to meet me and my family, and the heartfelt hospitality provided an intimate window into Bhutanese society. At weddings, dinner parties and gala events, we befriended a cross section of Bhutanese society, from the intelligence chief to a silversmith. We were awed by their aura of peace and kindness, prevalent qualities in Bhutan, no doubt because of the people's deep Buddhist faith and devotion to Gross National Happiness.
 One of our most interesting friends was named Iron Bridge. A lama, he is reputedly the 13th reincarnation of a Tibetan saint who built 108 iron bridges in Tibet and Bhutan in the 15th century. We met him at the wedding of a daughter of Pem L. Dorji, one of my golf charges who was the governor of Wangdi, the largest of Bhutan's 20 districts.
 While Carrie and I were dancing to a bizarre medley -- one moment a Bhutanese folk song by a live troupe and the next Bon Jovi's ''Living on a Prayer'' from a boom box -- I spotted Iron Bridge by the outdoor dance floor. Wearing a flowing, light gray, silk robe, he was lithe with a crew cut and gold wire-rim glasses. He radiated the tranquillity you'd expect from the Dalai Lama.
 I introduced myself, and Iron Bridge, in a mellifluous voice, replied: ''Glad to meet you. You do good works for our country.'' 
 I was stunned. How did a renowned lama know me? Turns out, Iron Bridge's father-in-law was Mr. Dorji.
 I peppered him with questions. He was 30 and had an 18-month-old daughter; he lived at his private monastery; and he had just finished five years of solitary meditation. He also had a business card, a fax number, an e-mail address and followers from Taipei to Los Angeles.
 ''Did you ever play golf?'' I said.
 ''No. I only have time to meditate,'' Iron Bridge replied.
 ''Maybe in your next life?'' I said.
 Iron Bridge smiled. ''Only if you teach me.''

HEADLINE: IN THE AIR, ON THE CHEAP

BYLINE: By BARRY ESTABROOK. 
BARRY ESTABROOK contributes to the Travel section regularly.

 BODY:
THE first indication that it was going to be an unusual airline experience was when the grandmotherly voiced agent who took my call at JetBlue Airways signed off by saying, ''Honey, you are so worth it.'' I expect a certain amount of attitude from airline employees, somewhere between sullen and downright surly. But respectful, efficient, friendly? It had been a long time since I had applied those adjectives to airline service. 
 That may be changing. JetBlue, which started in 2000, has attracted a loyal clientele by combining two seemingly contradictory philosophies: the low fares and single-class seating pioneered by Southwest plus frills and personality aplenty -- the airline is relaxed and hip. Following the lead of JetBlue, Delta started Song in April 2003, and United inaugurated Ted in February.
 Can these new airlines remain true to their low-cost premise while living up to their own hype with perks like leather seats, satellite television and personal service from attendants in designer uniforms? 
 The answer, says David Beckerman, a Washington-based director of consulting services at BACK Aviation Solutions, is not always. In early February, he analyzed fares on 15 popular United States routes and found that the major airlines beat low-cost carriers 55 percent of the time. ''Farther out, every airline looks about the same,'' Mr. Beckerman said. ''Close in, it is often the traditional carriers that are cheaper.''
 Ted, Song and JetBlue are very different entities, according to Michael Boyd, an airline consultant based in Evergreen, Colo. ''JetBlue is a stand-alone airline,'' Mr. Boyd said. ''They have built not so much a passenger base as a cult following by fostering the feeling that the company really likes to have people on its planes. Song is Delta's response to JetBlue. Ted is aviation shtick, pure and simple. United is spending money on a cute image, but it's basically the same fare, the same employees, and the same service as you got before they took United planes and painted Ted on their sides.''
 To see for myself, in mid-March I embarked on a 6,000-mile, 40-hour odyssey aboard JetBlue, Song and Ted. It would take me along the East Coast between New York and Florida, where Song and JetBlue compete, with a side trip from Fort Lauderdale to Denver and back, a route served by Ted. I took advantage of every perk and bought sample meals when offered.
 But first I had to get reservations. Twelve days before my departure, I went to JetBlue's Web site. Given the company's reputation for customer service and emphasis on electronic ticketing (it does not issue paper tickets), I expected a model of online efficiency. But the site was balky and slow. At one point, the screen said: ''Chill, this may take some time.'' How true. After 15 minutes, I gave up and called the airline. The grandmotherly-voiced woman got me a reservation, but couldn't assign a seat.
 My next stop was Song. A few clicks on its site and I had what I needed. Emboldened, I decided to buy an onboard meal, selecting an organic oregano-scented chicken and spinach salad, paying with my credit card. 
 Ted greeted me with bold navy blue and orange graphics, but after entering my flight information, I found myself on United's businesslike site, where booking went smoothly. Because I would be spending the night in Denver, Ted's base, I decided to use the Hotels feature on the site and reserved a king room at the Brown Palace for $130 a night. I called the hotel directly and asked for the same room. Their best price: $230.

First, JetBlue
 Still without a reserved seat on JetBlue, (800) 538-2583, www.jetblue.com, I lined up at the ticket counter in Burlington, Vt., the airport nearest my home, an hour before my scheduled departure to Kennedy Airport. There were two agents on duty and nine of us in line. One of the agents came around from behind the podium to speed up checking baggage. Another was helping passengers operate the touch-screen boarding pass terminals (which greeted us with the words ''Howdy'' and ''What's Up?'').
 At the gate, I grabbed my free earphones from a bin by the door and walked into the Jetway. The seats in the Airbus A-320 were upholstered in gray leather, and as soon as I sat down, I noticed that there was far more space between my seat and the one in front than is normal in coach. I had lucked out. Last year, JetBlue removed a row of seats from its planes to give more legroom -- 34 inches versus 32. But the change only affects rows 10 and higher, about two-thirds of the seats. I was in Row 21.
 The most noticeable difference between JetBlue and mainstream coach class, however, is the small TV screen on the back of every seat. I plugged in my earphones and tuned the DirecTV service to the ''Today'' show on NBC, one of 24 channels available. An hour later, after flight attendants had served me a free can of orange juice and a bag of chocolate oatmeal cookies, we landed at J.F.K. I hadn't even had time to try the exercises on the ''Airplane Yoga'' card in my seatback pouch. At $110 for a one-way ticket, it wasn't hard to understand why JetBlue is popular. The best fare I could find on a major airline for a one-way ticket from Burlington to Kennedy that close to departure was $184, on US Airways and United. Less obvious is how JetBlue has managed to be profitable for the past three years.
 ''We do more with less,'' said Gareth Edmondson-Jones, a company spokesman. ''Our planes fly 13 hours a day versus nine hours at many major airlines. Plus we have a very high load factor.'' For the first two months of this year, the airline filled 78 percent of its seats. Mr. Edmondson-Jones said that the airline, which announced the addition of four more cities to its routes in mid-March, for a total of 27, will be adding 16 Airbus planes this year.

Song in the Air
 Many of JetBlue's flights compete directly with Delta between the Northeast and Florida. According to Stacy Geagan, a spokeswoman for Song, (800) 359-7664, www.flysong.com, Florida is the source of 30 percent of Delta's global revenue. Ms. Geagan said that beginning last April, the company refurbished 36 Delta 757's as Song aircraft, with a bright green logo and leather interiors. Kate Spade created the charcoal-gray uniforms with parrot-green accents (and an optional butterfly-wing accent in place of the traditional airline wings) that attendants will begin wearing this month. By flying the planes longer hours each day, paying Delta flight attendants less per hour (and in exchange giving them the choice to work more hours per month) and using only one gate attendant to board planes, which can accommodate 199 passengers, Song has cut costs, Ms. Geagan said.
 But cutting the number of gate agents has a downside. I found the service at the J.F.K. gate slow and confusing. Once aboard, I was struck by the cheerful orange, green, purple and blue leather seats that offered 33 inches of legroom, more than usual in coach. Like JetBlue, every seat had a television screen. 
 It was getting close to noon, and my stomach was growling for that organic chicken salad I had ordered. I also had a thirst for a Song Sunrise, one of the airline's much-touted cocktails, a concoction of vodka, orange juice and cranapple juice served in a ''signature martini glass,'' according to the seat-pocket menu. Despite my having ordered online and paid $8, the flight attendant told me that they had run out of salads. ''You should have told us when you boarded,'' she said, curtly. Eventually, she found a salad in the galley. It was about half the size of the chicken salad sold at a deli in the terminal for $6.50, with a few tasteless squares of white meat on top of baby spinach leaves accompanied by a packet of Newman's Own balsamic dressing. I was still looking forward to sipping my Song Sunrise from that signature glass. Alas, the beverage ($5) came in the same cup as every other drink.
 The woman sitting next to me on the three-hour flight, Adriana Dieguez of Miami, who had flown to New York for the weekend, declined to pay for lunch, and was making do with a free Diet Coke. ''The amenities on this plane are fine,'' she said. ''But a little complimentary snack would have been nice for $270.'' Ms. Dieguez also found the in-flight service wanting. ''It's not customer-oriented,'' she said. ''They rushed us getting aboard.''
 Still, at $87, the Song flight was the best deal of my trip. The lowest I could get from a major airline was $281 (American).

The Name's Ted
 The cost of a round trip from Fort Lauderdale to Denver on Ted, (800) 225-5833, www.flyted.com, was $277. (American again had the best fare of a major: $323.) From the cute name (the last three letters of United) to the touch-screen terminals that invited me to ''Push Ted's buttons,'' and the bright orange placards in the boarding area that said things like, ''Ted is happy to see you,'' United has gone to extremes to make Ted aviation's answer to those up close and personal restaurant waiters of the 1990's.
 But Ted seemed to be suffering an identity crisis. Although we were surrounded by orange pillars and humorous slogans in the boarding area, the agent announced that United Flight 4321 was ready to board, then had to correct herself. Ted offers one-class service, but United's frequent fliers were allowed to board first. And were it not for the missing first-class cabin, the interior of Ted would have been identical to United's coach. There were no leather seats and no extra legroom in my row; an economy-plus section had more legroom, but those seats went first to the United frequent fliers.
 The flight attendants wore United uniforms. Tedevision, as the in-flight entertainment is called, was broadcast from overhead screens and consisted of reruns of popular shows such as ''Friends'' and ''Scrubs.'' 
 And although the touch screen that had invited me to push Ted's buttons had also assured me that I would be able to buy a restaurant-quality meal aboard the plane (a policy that applies to flights over two and a half hours), the flight attendant skipped our aisle, and by the time another attendant summoned her, the chicken salad I wanted was sold out. I settled for a $6 turkey pastrami sandwich that had a T.G.I. Friday's label but in all other ways reminded me of those tough, stale snacks they used to give out in coach for free. To Ted's credit, I was able to obliterate the taste with a bourbon on the rocks that cost $4, a dollar less than the same drink on the other flights.
 Rich Benvin, a professional tennis coach from Denver, was sitting across the aisle from me. He said he had reserved less than one week before departing for a spur-of-the-moment vacation to Florida, and it was not until he arrived at the terminal that he realized he was flying on Ted. ''I booked on United's site, and this feels like United to me,'' said Mr. Benvin, who is a frequent flier on United. ''They are using this whole Ted thing as a marketing ploy.''
 But Sean Donohue, vice president of Ted, said that there was much more to the airline than the cute image, which was developed by Pentagram Design of New York. ''We started Ted because, when you look at our fastest-growing markets like Denver to Phoenix and Denver to Fort Lauderdale, you see that they are being fueled by low fares,'' he said. ''Ted's costs are 15 to 20 percent below United's, which makes them comparable to Frontier.'' Frontier is a low-fare carrier that competes with United in Western markets. Mr. Donohue said that in its first month of operation, Ted flew with more than 80 percent of its seats filled. The airline will begin service this month out of Dulles, near Washington, and out of O'Hare, near Chicago, in May. 
 The final leg of my trip was back aboard JetBlue from Fort Lauderdale to J.F.K. The cost: $154. Each of the previous flights had been fairly full, but this one, scheduled to leave Fort Lauderdale at 5:50 p.m., was completely booked. The elderly couple next to me muttered to each other in Russian. Three bare-midriffed young ladies sat across the aisle and struck up a boisterous friendship with a trio of tattooed guys from Queens behind them. A couple with two active toddler boys sat behind me. It seemed that everyone except me had brought carry-on food. We were a raucous crew, but despite the pandemonium, the flight attendants took it in stride, smiling and chatting as they served free soft drinks and bags of blue potato chips, biscotti and cookies. 
 The sky darkened. I turned up the volume on my headphones to shut out the chatter and assessed my two days in this new world of commercial flight. I loved the leather seats, extra room and satellite TV on JetBlue and Song. But next time I fly Song, I'll buy food at the airport and carry it on. Flying Ted is virtually the same as flying coach on any other airline. And I'll take the smiles and can-do attitudes I encountered on JetBlue over designer uniforms any day.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 4 about three low-fare airlines misstated the location of O'Hare Airport, where one airline, Ted, will begin service next month. The airport is in Chicago, not merely near it.
